   <h1 class="firstHeading" id="firstHeading" lang="en">
    Japan
   </h1>
   <div class="mw-body-content" id="bodyContent">
    <div id="siteSub">
     From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia
    </div>

     <table class="metadata mbox-small noprint selfref" role="presentation" style="border:1px solid #aaa;background-color:#f9f9f9;width: 22em;">
      <tr>
       <td class="mbox-image">
        <img alt="" data-file-height="224" data-file-width="100" height="40" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a5/Nihongo.svg/18px-Nihongo.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a5/Nihongo.svg/27px-Nihongo.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a5/Nihongo.svg/35px-Nihongo.svg.png 2x" width="18"/>
       </td>
       <td class="mbox-text plainlist" style="vertical-align:middle; font-size:95%;">
        You may need
        <a href="/wiki/Help:Installing_Japanese_character_sets" title="Help:Installing Japanese character sets">
         rendering support
        </a>
        to display the
        <a href="/wiki/Japanese_language" title="Japanese language">
         Japanese
        </a>
        text in this article correctly.
       </td>
      </tr>
     </table>
     <p>
      <b>
       Japan
      </b>
      (
      <a href="/wiki/Japanese_language" title="Japanese language">
       Japanese
      </a>
      :
      <span lang="ja">
       日本
      </span>
      <i>
       Nippon
      </i>
      <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
       <a href="/wiki/Help:IPA_for_Japanese" title="Help:IPA for Japanese">
        [nip̚põ̞ɴ]
       </a>
      </span>
      or
      <i>
       Nihon
      </i>
      <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
       <a href="/wiki/Help:IPA_for_Japanese" title="Help:IPA for Japanese">
        [nihõ̞ɴ]
       </a>
      </span>
      ; formally
      <span class="t_nihongo_kanji">
       <span lang="ja">
        日本国
       </span>
      </span>
      <i>
       <span class="unicode haudio">
        <span class="fn">
         <span style="white-space:nowrap">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Ja-nippon_nihonkoku.ogg" title="About this sound">
           <img alt="About this sound" data-file-height="20" data-file-width="20" height="11" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/11px-Loudspeaker.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/17px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/22px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 2x" width="11"/>
          </a>
         </span>
         <a class="internal" href="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/8/86/Ja-nippon_nihonkoku.ogg" title="Ja-nippon nihonkoku.ogg">
          Nippon-koku
         </a>
        </span>
       </span>
      </i>
      or
      <i>
       Nihon-koku
      </i>
      , "State of Japan") is an
      <a href="/wiki/Island_country" title="Island country">
       island country
      </a>
      in
      <a href="/wiki/East_Asia" title="East Asia">
       East Asia
      </a>
      . Located in the
      <a href="/wiki/Pacific_Ocean" title="Pacific Ocean">
       Pacific Ocean
      </a>
      , it lies to the east of the
      <a href="/wiki/Sea_of_Japan" title="Sea of Japan">
       Sea of Japan
      </a>
      , the
      <a href="/wiki/East_China_Sea" title="East China Sea">
       East China Sea
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/China" title="China">
       China
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Korea" title="Korea">
       Korea
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Russia" title="Russia">
       Russia
      </a>
      , stretching from the
      <a href="/wiki/Sea_of_Okhotsk" title="Sea of Okhotsk">
       Sea of Okhotsk
      </a>
      in the north to the East China Sea and
      <a href="/wiki/Taiwan" title="Taiwan">
       Taiwan
      </a>
      in the south. The
      <a href="/wiki/Kanji" title="Kanji">
       kanji
      </a>
      that make up
      <a href="/wiki/Names_of_Japan" title="Names of Japan">
       Japan's name
      </a>
      mean "sun origin", and it is often called the "Land of the Rising Sun".
     </p>
     <p>
      Japan is a
      <a href="/wiki/Stratovolcano" title="Stratovolcano">
       stratovolcanic
      </a>
      <a href="/wiki/Archipelago" title="Archipelago">
       archipelago
      </a>
      of
      <a href="/wiki/List_of_islands_of_Japan" title="List of islands of Japan">
       6,852 islands
      </a>
      . The four largest are
      <a href="/wiki/Honshu" title="Honshu">
       Honshu
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Hokkaido" title="Hokkaido">
       Hokkaido
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Kyushu" title="Kyushu">
       Kyushu
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Shikoku" title="Shikoku">
       Shikoku
      </a>
      , which make up about ninety-seven percent of Japan's land area. The country is divided into 47
      <a href="/wiki/Prefectures_of_Japan" title="Prefectures of Japan">
       prefectures
      </a>
      in eight
      <a href="/wiki/List_of_regions_of_Japan" title="List of regions of Japan">
       regions
      </a>
      . The population of 126 million is the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_population" title="List of countries by population">
       world's tenth largest
      </a>
      .
      <a href="/wiki/Japanese_people" title="Japanese people">
       Japanese people
      </a>
      make up 98.5% of Japan's total population. Approximately 9.1 million people live in the core city of
      <a href="/wiki/Tokyo" title="Tokyo">
       Tokyo
      </a>
      ,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-9">
       <a href="#cite_note-9">
        [9]
       </a>
      </sup>
      the
      <a href="/wiki/Capital_of_Japan" title="Capital of Japan">
       capital city of Japan
      </a>
      , which is the
      <a href="/wiki/List_of_cities_proper_by_population" title="List of cities proper by population">
       sixth largest city proper
      </a>
      in the
      <a href="/wiki/Organisation_for_Economic_Co-operation_and_Development" title="Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development">
       OECD
      </a>
      and the fourth leading
      <a href="/wiki/Global_city" title="Global city">
       global city
      </a>
      in the world.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-10">
       <a href="#cite_note-10">
        [10]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The
      <a href="/wiki/Greater_Tokyo_Area" title="Greater Tokyo Area">
       Greater Tokyo Area
      </a>
      , which includes Tokyo and several surrounding
      <a href="/wiki/Prefectures_of_Japan" title="Prefectures of Japan">
       prefectures
      </a>
      , is the
      <a href="/wiki/World%27s_largest_cities" title="World's largest cities">
       world's largest metropolitan area
      </a>
      with over 35 million residents and the
      <a href="/wiki/List_of_cities_by_GDP" title="List of cities by GDP">
       world's largest urban agglomeration economy
      </a>
      .
     </p>
     <p>
      Archaeological research indicates that Japan was inhabited as early as the
      <a href="/wiki/Upper_Paleolithic" title="Upper Paleolithic">
       Upper Paleolithic
      </a>
      period. The first written mention of Japan is in
      <a href="/wiki/History_of_China" title="History of China">
       Chinese history
      </a>
      texts from the 1st century AD. Influence from other regions, mainly
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Imperial_China" title="Imperial China">
       Imperial China
      </a>
      , followed by periods of isolation, particularly from Western Europe, has characterized
      <a href="/wiki/History_of_Japan" title="History of Japan">
       Japan's history
      </a>
      . From the 12th century until 1868, Japan was ruled by successive feudal military
      <a href="/wiki/Shogun" title="Shogun">
       shoguns
      </a>
      who ruled in the name of the
      <a href="/wiki/Emperor_of_Japan" title="Emperor of Japan">
       Emperor
      </a>
      . Japan entered into a long period of isolation in the early 17th century, which was ended in 1853 when a United States fleet
      <a href="/wiki/Bakumatsu" title="Bakumatsu">
       pressured Japan
      </a>
      to open to the West. Nearly two decades of internal conflict and insurrection followed before the
      <a href="/wiki/Emperor_Meiji" title="Emperor Meiji">
       Meiji Emperor
      </a>
      was restored as head of state in 1868 and the
      <a href="/wiki/Empire_of_Japan" title="Empire of Japan">
       Empire of Japan
      </a>
      was proclaimed, with the Emperor as a divine symbol of the nation. In the late 19th and early 20th centuries, victories in the
      <a href="/wiki/First_Sino-Japanese_War" title="First Sino-Japanese War">
       First Sino-Japanese War
      </a>
      , the
      <a href="/wiki/Russo-Japanese_War" title="Russo-Japanese War">
       Russo-Japanese War
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/World_War_I" title="World War I">
       World War I
      </a>
      allowed Japan to expand its empire during a period of increasing militarism. The
      <a href="/wiki/Second_Sino-Japanese_War" title="Second Sino-Japanese War">
       Second Sino-Japanese War
      </a>
      of 1937 expanded into part of
      <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">
       World War II
      </a>
      in 1941, which came to an
      <a href="/wiki/End_of_World_War_II_in_Asia" title="End of World War II in Asia">
       end in 1945
      </a>
      following the
      <a href="/wiki/Atomic_bombings_of_Hiroshima_and_Nagasaki" title="Atomic bombings of Hiroshima and Nagasaki">
       atomic bombings of Hiroshima and Nagasaki
      </a>
      . Since adopting its revised
      <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Japan" title="Constitution of Japan">
       constitution
      </a>
      in 1947, Japan has maintained a unitary
      <a href="/wiki/Constitutional_monarchy" title="Constitutional monarchy">
       constitutional monarchy
      </a>
      with an
      <a href="/wiki/Emperor_of_Japan" title="Emperor of Japan">
       Emperor
      </a>
      and an elected legislature called the
      <a href="/wiki/National_Diet" title="National Diet">
       National Diet
      </a>
      .
     </p>
     <p>
      Japan is a member of the
      <a href="/wiki/United_Nations" title="United Nations">
       UN
      </a>
      , the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Group_of_Seven_(G7)" title="Group of Seven (G7)">
       G7
      </a>
      , the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Group_of_Eight_(G8)" title="Group of Eight (G8)">
       G8
      </a>
      , and the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/G-20_major_economies" title="G-20 major economies">
       G20
      </a>
      and is considered a
      <a href="/wiki/Great_power" title="Great power">
       great power
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-11">
       <a href="#cite_note-11">
        [11]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Balance_of_Power_12-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Balance_of_Power-12">
        [12]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Joshua_Baron_13-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Joshua_Baron-13">
        [13]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The country has the world's third-largest
      <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(nominal)" title="List of countries by GDP (nominal)">
       economy by nominal GDP
      </a>
      and the world's fourth-largest
      <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(PPP)" title="List of countries by GDP (PPP)">
       economy by purchasing power parity
      </a>
      . It is also the world's
      <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_exports" title="List of countries by exports">
       fourth-largest exporter
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_imports" title="List of countries by imports">
       fourth-largest importer
      </a>
      . The country benefits from a highly skilled workforce and is among the most educated countries in the world with the one of the highest percentage of its citizens holding a tertiary education degree.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-OECD_14-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-OECD-14">
        [14]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Although Japan has officially
      <a href="/wiki/Article_9_of_the_Japanese_Constitution" title="Article 9 of the Japanese Constitution">
       renounced its right to declare war
      </a>
      , it maintains a
      <a href="/wiki/Japan_Self-Defense_Forces" title="Japan Self-Defense Forces">
       modern military
      </a>
      with the world's
      <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_military_expenditures" title="List of countries by military expenditures">
       eighth largest military budget
      </a>
      ,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-15">
       <a href="#cite_note-15">
        [15]
       </a>
      </sup>
      used for
      <a href="/wiki/Self-defense" title="Self-defense">
       self-defense
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Peacekeeping" title="Peacekeeping">
       peacekeeping
      </a>
      roles. Japan is a
      <a href="/wiki/Developed_country" title="Developed country">
       developed country
      </a>
      with a high standard of living and
      <a href="/wiki/Human_Development_Index" title="Human Development Index">
       Human Development Index
      </a>
      whose population enjoys the
      <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_life_expectancy" title="List of countries by life expectancy">
       highest life expectancy
      </a>
      and the third lowest
      <a href="/wiki/Infant_mortality" title="Infant mortality">
       infant mortality
      </a>
      in the world.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-16">
       <a href="#cite_note-16">
        [16]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Table_A.17_17-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Table_A.17-17">
        [17]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
     </p>

     <p>
     </p>
     <h2>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Etymology">
       Etymology
      </span>
     </h2>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Main article:
      <a href="/wiki/Names_of_Japan" title="Names of Japan">
       Names of Japan
      </a>
     </div>
     <div class="thumb tleft">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Uji-bashi_03.JPG">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="576" data-file-width="768" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/56/Uji-bashi_03.JPG/220px-Uji-bashi_03.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/56/Uji-bashi_03.JPG/330px-Uji-bashi_03.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/56/Uji-bashi_03.JPG/440px-Uji-bashi_03.JPG 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Uji-bashi_03.JPG" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        Japan is popularly called as
        <i>
         Land of the Rising Sun
        </i>
        , since it lies in eastward position in relation to the Asian mainland
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      The Japanese word for Japan is
      <span class="t_nihongo_kanji">
       <span lang="ja">
        日本
       </span>
      </span>
      , which is pronounced Nippon or Nihon. The English word
      <i>
       Japan
      </i>
      possibly derives from the historical
      <a href="/wiki/Chinese_language" title="Chinese language">
       Chinese
      </a>
      pronunciation of 日本. The
      <a href="/wiki/Old_Mandarin" title="Old Mandarin">
       Old Mandarin
      </a>
      or possibly early
      <a href="/wiki/Wu_Chinese" title="Wu Chinese">
       Wu Chinese
      </a>
      pronunciation of Japan was recorded by
      <a href="/wiki/Marco_Polo" title="Marco Polo">
       Marco Polo
      </a>
      as
      <i>
       Cipangu
      </i>
      . In modern
      <a href="/wiki/Shanghainese" title="Shanghainese">
       Shanghainese
      </a>
      , a Wu dialect, the pronunciation of characters
      <span class="t_nihongo_kanji">
       <span lang="ja">
        日本
       </span>
      </span>
      Japan is
      <i>
       Zeppen
      </i>
      <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
       <a href="/wiki/Help:IPA" title="Help:IPA">
        [zəʔpən]
       </a>
      </span>
      . The old
      <a href="/wiki/Malay_language" title="Malay language">
       Malay
      </a>
      word for Japan,
      <i>
       Jepang
      </i>
      , was borrowed from a southern coastal Chinese dialect, probably
      <a href="/wiki/Hokkien" title="Hokkien">
       Fukienese
      </a>
      or
      <a href="/wiki/Ningbo_dialect" title="Ningbo dialect">
       Ningpo
      </a>
      ,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-18">
       <a href="#cite_note-18">
        [18]
       </a>
      </sup>
      and this Malay word was encountered by
      <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_Empire" title="Portuguese Empire">
       Portuguese
      </a>
      traders in
      <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_Malacca" title="Portuguese Malacca">
       Malacca
      </a>
      in the 16th century.
      <a href="/wiki/Nanban_trade" title="Nanban trade">
       Early Portuguese traders
      </a>
      then brought the word to
      <a href="/wiki/Europe" title="Europe">
       Europe
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-19">
       <a href="#cite_note-19">
        [19]
       </a>
      </sup>
      An early record of the word in English is in a 1565 letter, spelled
      <i>
       Giapan
      </i>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-20">
       <a href="#cite_note-20">
        [20]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      From the
      <a href="/wiki/Meiji_Restoration" title="Meiji Restoration">
       Meiji Restoration
      </a>
      until the end of
      <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">
       World War II
      </a>
      , the full title of Japan was
      <i>
       Dai Nippon Teikoku
      </i>
      <span style="font-weight: normal">
       (
       <span class="t_nihongo_kanji" lang="ja">
        大日本帝國
       </span>
       )
      </span>
      , meaning "the
      <a href="/wiki/Empire_of_Japan" title="Empire of Japan">
       Empire of Great Japan
      </a>
      ". Today the name
      <i>
       Nippon-koku / Nihon-koku
      </i>
      <span style="font-weight: normal">
       (
       <span class="t_nihongo_kanji" lang="ja">
        日本国
       </span>
       )
      </span>
      is used as a formal modern-day equivalent simply meaning "the State of Japan"; countries like Japan whose long form does not contain a descriptive designation are generally given a name appended by the character
      <i>
       koku
      </i>
      <span style="font-weight: normal">
       (
       <span class="t_nihongo_kanji" lang="ja">
        国
       </span>
       )
      </span>
      , meaning "country", "nation" or "state".
     </p>
     <p>
      The character
      <i>
       nichi
      </i>
      <span style="font-weight: normal">
       (
       <span class="t_nihongo_kanji" lang="ja">
        日
       </span>
       )
      </span>
      means "sun" or "day";
      <i>
       hon
      </i>
      <span style="font-weight: normal">
       (
       <span class="t_nihongo_kanji" lang="ja">
        本
       </span>
       )
      </span>
      means "base" or "origin". The compound means "origin of the sun" or "sunrise", and is the source of the popular Western epithet "Land of the Rising Sun".
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-21">
       <a href="#cite_note-21">
        [21]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h2>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="History">
       History
      </span>
     </h2>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Main article:
      <a href="/wiki/History_of_Japan" title="History of Japan">
       History of Japan
      </a>
     </div>
     <table class="vertical-navbox nowraplinks" style="float:right;clear:right;width:22.0em;margin:0 0 1.0em 1.0em;background:#f9f9f9;border:1px solid #aaa;padding:0.2em;border-spacing:0.4em 0;text-align:center;line-height:1.4em;font-size:88%">
      <tr>
       <th style="padding:0.2em 0.4em 0.2em;font-size:145%;line-height:1.2em">
        <a href="/wiki/History_of_Japan" title="History of Japan">
         History of Japan
        </a>
       </th>
      </tr>
      <tr>
       <td style="padding:0.2em 0 0.4em">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Naiku_01.JPG">
         <img alt="Naiku 01.JPG" data-file-height="768" data-file-width="1024" height="188" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c9/Naiku_01.JPG/250px-Naiku_01.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c9/Naiku_01.JPG/375px-Naiku_01.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c9/Naiku_01.JPG/500px-Naiku_01.JPG 2x" width="250"/>
        </a>
       </td>
      </tr>

             </a>
            </td>
