         United Kingdom
        </a>
       </td>
       <td>
        258,488
       </td>
       <td>
        17.5%
       </td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
       <td>
        12
       </td>
       <td>
        <span class="flagicon">
         <img alt="" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="500" data-file-width="1000" height="12" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/c/cf/Flag_of_Canada.svg/23px-Flag_of_Canada.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/c/cf/Flag_of_Canada.svg/35px-Flag_of_Canada.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/c/cf/Flag_of_Canada.svg/46px-Flag_of_Canada.svg.png 2x" width="23"/>
        </span>
        <a href="/wiki/Canada" title="Canada">
         Canada
        </a>
       </td>
       <td>
        231,390
       </td>
       <td>
        26.5%
       </td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
       <td>
       </td>
       <td>
        All countries
       </td>
       <td>
        19,737,409
       </td>
       <td>
        47.1%
       </td>
      </tr>
     </table>
     <p>
      Neighbouring South Korea is Japan's most important source of foreign tourists. In 2010, the 2.4 million arrivals made up 27% of the tourists visiting Japan.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Dickie_166-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Dickie-166">
        [166]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Chinese travelers are the highest spenders in Japan by country, spending an estimated 196.4 billion yen (US$2.4 billion) in 2011, or almost a quarter of total expenditure by foreign visitors, according to data from the Japan Tourism Agency.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-167">
       <a href="#cite_note-167">
        [167]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      The Japanese government hopes to receive 40 million foreign tourists every year by 2020.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-10year_168-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-10year-168">
        [168]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h2>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Science_and_technology">
       Science and technology
      </span>
     </h2>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Main article:
      <a href="/wiki/Science_and_technology_in_Japan" title="Science and technology in Japan">
       Science and technology in Japan
      </a>
     </div>
     <p>
      Japan is a leading nation in
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Scientific_research" title="Scientific research">
       scientific research
      </a>
      , particularly in fields related to the natural sciences,
      <a href="/wiki/Electronics" title="Electronics">
       electronics
      </a>
      , engineering and the life sciences. The country ranks second among the most innovative countries in the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bloomberg_Innovation_Index" title="Bloomberg Innovation Index">
       Bloomberg Innovation Index
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-169">
       <a href="#cite_note-169">
        [169]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-170">
       <a href="#cite_note-170">
        [170]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Nearly 700,000 researchers share a US$130 billion
      <a href="/wiki/Research_and_development" title="Research and development">
       research and development
      </a>
      budget.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-171">
       <a href="#cite_note-171">
        [171]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The amount spent on
      <a href="/wiki/Research_and_development" title="Research and development">
       research and development
      </a>
      relative to its gross domestic product
      <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_research_and_development_spending" title="List of countries by research and development spending">
       third highest in the world
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-172">
       <a href="#cite_note-172">
        [172]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The country is a world leader in
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Fundamental_research" title="Fundamental research">
       fundamental scientific research
      </a>
      , having produced twenty-two
      <a href="/wiki/Nobel_Prize" title="Nobel Prize">
       Nobel laureates
      </a>
      in either physics, chemistry or medicine,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-173">
       <a href="#cite_note-173">
        [173]
       </a>
      </sup>
      and three
      <a href="/wiki/Fields_Medal" title="Fields Medal">
       Fields medalists
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-174">
       <a href="#cite_note-174">
        [174]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Japanese scientists and engineers have contributed to the advancement of electronics,
      <a href="/wiki/Industrial_robot" title="Industrial robot">
       industrial robotics
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Optics" title="Optics">
       optics
      </a>
      , chemicals,
      <a href="/wiki/Semiconductor" title="Semiconductor">
       semiconductors
      </a>
      ,
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Life_science" title="Life science">
       life sciences
      </a>
      and various fields of engineering. Japan leads the world in
      <a href="/wiki/Robotics" title="Robotics">
       robotics
      </a>
      production and use, possessing more than 20% (300,000 of 1.3 million) of the world's industrial robots as of 2013
      <sup class="plainlinks noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;">
       <a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Japan&amp;action=edit">
        [update]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-175">
       <a href="#cite_note-175">
        [175]
       </a>
      </sup>
      —though its share was historically even higher, representing one-half of all industrial robots worldwide in 2000.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-176">
       <a href="#cite_note-176">
        [176]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Japan boasts the third highest number of scientists, technicians, and engineers per capita in the world with 83 scientists, technicians, and engineers per 10,000 employees.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-177">
       <a href="#cite_note-177">
        [177]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-178">
       <a href="#cite_note-178">
        [178]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-179">
       <a href="#cite_note-179">
        [179]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Electronics_and_automotive">
       Electronics and automotive
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Prius_Plug-in_Hybrid-11-09-04-iaa-by-RalfR-108.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="800" data-file-width="1388" height="127" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6a/Prius_Plug-in_Hybrid-11-09-04-iaa-by-RalfR-108.jpg/220px-Prius_Plug-in_Hybrid-11-09-04-iaa-by-RalfR-108.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6a/Prius_Plug-in_Hybrid-11-09-04-iaa-by-RalfR-108.jpg/330px-Prius_Plug-in_Hybrid-11-09-04-iaa-by-RalfR-108.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6a/Prius_Plug-in_Hybrid-11-09-04-iaa-by-RalfR-108.jpg/440px-Prius_Plug-in_Hybrid-11-09-04-iaa-by-RalfR-108.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Prius_Plug-in_Hybrid-11-09-04-iaa-by-RalfR-108.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        A plug-in
        <a href="/wiki/Hybrid_vehicle" title="Hybrid vehicle">
         hybrid car
        </a>
        manufactured by
        <a href="/wiki/Toyota" title="Toyota">
         Toyota
        </a>
        , one of the world's largest carmakers. Japan is the second-largest producer of automobiles in the world.
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-180">
         <a href="#cite_note-180">
          [180]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      Japan is well known for its
      <a href="/wiki/Electronics" title="Electronics">
       electronics
      </a>
      industry throughout the world, and Japanese electronic products account for a large share in the world market, compared to a majority of other countries. Japan is one of the leading nations in the fields of scientific research, technology, machinery, and medical research with the world's third largest budget for research and development at $130 billion
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/USD" title="USD">
       USD
      </a>
      , and over 677,731 researchers.
     </p>
     <p>
      Japan has large international corporate conglomerates such as
      <a href="/wiki/Fujifilm" title="Fujifilm">
       Fujifilm
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Sony" title="Sony">
       Sony
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Panasonic" title="Panasonic">
       Panasonic
      </a>
      ,
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Canon_(company)" title="Canon (company)">
       Canon
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Fujitsu" title="Fujitsu">
       Fujitsu
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Hitachi" title="Hitachi">
       Hitachi
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Sharp_Corporation" title="Sharp Corporation">
       Sharp
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/NEC" title="NEC">
       NEC
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Nintendo" title="Nintendo">
       Nintendo
      </a>
      ,
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Epson" title="Epson">
       Epson
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Toshiba" title="Toshiba">
       Toshiba
      </a>
      are among the best-known electronics companies in the world.
      <a href="/wiki/Toyota" title="Toyota">
       Toyota
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Honda" title="Honda">
       Honda
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Nissan" title="Nissan">
       Nissan
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Mazda" title="Mazda">
       Mazda
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Mitsubishi" title="Mitsubishi">
       Mitsubishi
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Suzuki" title="Suzuki">
       Suzuki
      </a>
      , and
      <a href="/wiki/Subaru" title="Subaru">
       Subaru
      </a>
      are also very well known automobile companies in the world.
     </p>
     <p>
      It's estimated that 16% of the world's gold and 22% of the world's silver is contained in electronic technology in Japan.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-181">
       <a href="#cite_note-181">
        [181]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Aerospace">
       Aerospace
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Kibo_PM_and_ELM-PS.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2039" data-file-width="3072" height="146" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a7/Kibo_PM_and_ELM-PS.jpg/220px-Kibo_PM_and_ELM-PS.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a7/Kibo_PM_and_ELM-PS.jpg/330px-Kibo_PM_and_ELM-PS.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a7/Kibo_PM_and_ELM-PS.jpg/440px-Kibo_PM_and_ELM-PS.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Kibo_PM_and_ELM-PS.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        The
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Japanese_Experiment_Module" title="Japanese Experiment Module">
         Japanese Experiment Module
        </a>
        (Kibo) at the
        <a href="/wiki/International_Space_Station" title="International Space Station">
         International Space Station
        </a>
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      The
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Japan_Aerospace_Exploration_Agency" title="Japan Aerospace Exploration Agency">
       Japan Aerospace Exploration Agency
      </a>
      (JAXA) is Japan's
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Space_agency" title="Space agency">
       space agency
      </a>
      ; it conducts space, planetary, and aviation research, and leads development of rockets and satellites. It is a participant in the
      <a href="/wiki/International_Space_Station" title="International Space Station">
       International Space Station
      </a>
      : the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Japanese_Experiment_Module" title="Japanese Experiment Module">
       Japanese Experiment Module
      </a>
      (Kibo) was added to the station during
      <a href="/wiki/Space_Shuttle" title="Space Shuttle">
       Space Shuttle
      </a>
      assembly flights in 2008.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-182">
       <a href="#cite_note-182">
        [182]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Japan's plans in
      <a href="/wiki/Space_exploration" title="Space exploration">
       space exploration
      </a>
      include: launching a
      <a href="/wiki/Space_probe" title="Space probe">
       space probe
      </a>
      to
      <a href="/wiki/Venus" title="Venus">
       Venus
      </a>
      ,
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Akatsuki_(spacecraft)" title="Akatsuki (spacecraft)">
        Akatsuki
       </a>
      </i>
      ;
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-183">
       <a href="#cite_note-183">
        [183]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-184">
       <a href="#cite_note-184">
        [184]
       </a>
      </sup>
      developing the
      <i>
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mercury_Magnetospheric_Orbiter" title="Mercury Magnetospheric Orbiter">
        Mercury Magnetospheric Orbiter
       </a>
      </i>
      to be launched in 2016;
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FACTS_185-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-FACTS-185">
        [185]
       </a>
      </sup>
      and building a
      <a href="/wiki/Colonization_of_the_Moon" title="Colonization of the Moon">
       moon base
      </a>
      by 2030.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-186">
       <a href="#cite_note-186">
        [186]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      On September 14, 2007, it launched lunar explorer "
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/SELENE" title="SELENE">
        SELENE
       </a>
      </i>
      " (
      <b>
       Sel
      </b>
      enological and
      <b>
       En
      </b>
      gineering
      <b>
       E
      </b>
      xplorer) on an
      <a href="/wiki/H-IIA" title="H-IIA">
       H-IIA
      </a>
      (Model H2A2022) carrier rocket from
      <a href="/wiki/Tanegashima_Space_Center" title="Tanegashima Space Center">
       Tanegashima Space Center
      </a>
      .
      <i>
       SELENE
      </i>
      is also known as
      <i>
       Kaguya
      </i>
      , after the lunar princess of
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/The_Tale_of_the_Bamboo_Cutter" title="The Tale of the Bamboo Cutter">
        The Tale of the Bamboo Cutter
       </a>
      </i>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-jaxa_nickname_187-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-jaxa_nickname-187">
        [187]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <i>
       Kaguya
      </i>
      is the largest lunar mission since the
      <a href="/wiki/Apollo_program" title="Apollo program">
       Apollo program
      </a>
      . Its purpose is to gather data on the
      <a href="/wiki/Moon#Formation" title="Moon">
       moon's origin and evolution
      </a>
      . It entered a lunar orbit on October 4,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-188">
       <a href="#cite_note-188">
        [188]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-189">
       <a href="#cite_note-189">
        [189]
       </a>
      </sup>
      flying at an altitude of about 100 km (62 mi).
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-190">
       <a href="#cite_note-190">
        [190]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The probe's mission was ended when it was deliberately crashed by JAXA into the Moon on June 11, 2009.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-191">
       <a href="#cite_note-191">
        [191]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Nobel_laureates">
       Nobel laureates
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Main article:
      <a href="/wiki/List_of_Japanese_Nobel_laureates" title="List of Japanese Nobel laureates">
       List of Japanese Nobel laureates
      </a>
     </div>
     <p>
      Japan has received the most science
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Nobel_prize" title="Nobel prize">
       Nobel prizes
      </a>
      in Asia and ranked 8th in the world.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-192">
       <a href="#cite_note-192">
        [192]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Japanese researchers have won several
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Nobel_prize" title="Nobel prize">
       Nobel prizes
      </a>
      .
      <a href="/wiki/Hideki_Yukawa" title="Hideki Yukawa">
       Hideki Yukawa
      </a>
      , educated at
      <a href="/wiki/Kyoto_University" title="Kyoto University">
       Kyoto University
      </a>
      , was awarded the prize for physics in 1949.
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sin-Itiro_Tomonaga" title="Sin-Itiro Tomonaga">
       Sin-Itiro Tomonaga
      </a>
      followed in 1965. Solid-state physicist
      <a href="/wiki/Leo_Esaki" title="Leo Esaki">
       Leo Esaki
      </a>
      , educated at the
      <a href="/wiki/University_of_Tokyo" title="University of Tokyo">
       University of Tokyo
      </a>
      , received the prize in 1973.
      <a href="/wiki/Kenichi_Fukui" title="Kenichi Fukui">
       Kenichi Fukui
      </a>
      of Kyoto University shared the 1981 chemistry prize, and
      <a href="/wiki/Susumu_Tonegawa" title="Susumu Tonegawa">
       Susumu Tonegawa
      </a>
      , also educated at Kyoto University, became Japan's first (and, as of 2007, only) laureate in physiology or medicine in 1987. Japanese chemists took prizes in 2000 and 2001: first
      <a href="/wiki/Hideki_Shirakawa" title="Hideki Shirakawa">
       Hideki Shirakawa
      </a>
      (
      <a href="/wiki/Tokyo_Institute_of_Technology" title="Tokyo Institute of Technology">
       Tokyo Institute of Technology
      </a>
      ) and then
      <a href="/wiki/Ry%C5%8Dji_Noyori" title="Ryōji Noyori">
       Ryōji Noyori
      </a>
      (Kyoto University).
      <a href="/wiki/Masatoshi_Koshiba" title="Masatoshi Koshiba">
       Masatoshi Koshiba
      </a>
      (University of Tokyo) and
      <a href="/wiki/Koichi_Tanaka" title="Koichi Tanaka">
       Koichi Tanaka
      </a>
      (
      <a href="/wiki/Tohoku_University" title="Tohoku University">
       Tohoku University
      </a>
      ) won in physics and chemistry, respectively, in 2002.
      <a href="/wiki/Makoto_Kobayashi_(physicist)" title="Makoto Kobayashi (physicist)">
       Makoto Kobayashi
      </a>
      ,
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Toshihide_Masukawa" title="Toshihide Masukawa">
       Toshihide Masukawa
      </a>
      , and
      <a href="/wiki/Yoichiro_Nambu" title="Yoichiro Nambu">
       Yoichiro Nambu
      </a>
      who is an American citizen when awarded, shared the physics prize and
      <a href="/wiki/Osamu_Shimomura" title="Osamu Shimomura">
       Osamu Shimomura
      </a>
      also won the chemistry prize in 2008.
      <a href="/wiki/Isamu_Akasaki" title="Isamu Akasaki">
       Isamu Akasaki
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Hiroshi_Amano" title="Hiroshi Amano">
       Hiroshi Amano
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Shuji_Nakamura" title="Shuji Nakamura">
       Shuji Nakamura
      </a>
      , who is an American citizen when awarded, shared the physics prize in 2014, and the Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine was awarded to Yoshinori Ohsumi in 2016.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-193">
       <a href="#cite_note-193">
        [193]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h2>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Infrastructure">
       Infrastructure
      </span>
     </h2>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Transportation">
       Transportation
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Main article:
      <a href="/wiki/Transport_in_Japan" title="Transport in Japan">
       Transport in Japan
      </a>
     </div>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:JRE-TEC-E5_omiya.JPG">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2463" data-file-width="3552" height="153" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b4/JRE-TEC-E5_omiya.JPG/220px-JRE-TEC-E5_omiya.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b4/JRE-TEC-E5_omiya.JPG/330px-JRE-TEC-E5_omiya.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b4/JRE-TEC-E5_omiya.JPG/440px-JRE-TEC-E5_omiya.JPG 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:JRE-TEC-E5_omiya.JPG" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        A JR East E5 series
        <a href="/wiki/Shinkansen" title="Shinkansen">
         shinkansen
        </a>
        (bullet train)
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      Japan's road spending has been extensive.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-194">
       <a href="#cite_note-194">
        [194]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Its 1.2 million kilometres (0.75 million miles) of paved road are the main means of transportation.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-195">
       <a href="#cite_note-195">
        [195]
       </a>
      </sup>
      As of April 2012 Japan has approximately 1,215,000 km of roads made up of 1,022,000 km of city, town and village roads, 129,000 km of prefectural roads, 55,000 km of general national highways and 8,050 km of national
      <a href="/wiki/Expressways_of_Japan" title="Expressways of Japan">
       expressways
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-196">
       <a href="#cite_note-196">
        [196]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-197">
       <a href="#cite_note-197">
        [197]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The
      <a class="external text" href="http://fpcj.jp/" rel="nofollow">
       Foreign Press Center/Japan
      </a>
      cites a total length of expressways at 7,641 km (fiscal 2008).
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-198">
       <a href="#cite_note-198">
        [198]
       </a>
      </sup>
      A single network of high-speed, divided, limited-access
      <a href="/wiki/Toll_road" title="Toll road">
       toll roads
      </a>
      connects major cities on
      <a href="/wiki/Honshu" title="Honshu">
       Honshu
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Shikoku" title="Shikoku">
       Shikoku
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Kyushu" title="Kyushu">
       Kyushu
      </a>
      .
      <a href="/wiki/Hokkaido" title="Hokkaido">
       Hokkaido
      </a>
      has a separate network, and
      <a href="/wiki/Okinawa_Island" title="Okinawa Island">
       Okinawa Island
      </a>
      has a highway of this type. A single network of high-speed, divided, limited-access
      <a href="/wiki/Toll_road" title="Toll road">
       toll roads
      </a>
      connects major cities and is operated by toll-collecting enterprises. New and used cars are inexpensive; car ownership fees and fuel levies are used to promote energy efficiency. However, at just 50 percent of all distance traveled, car usage is the lowest of all G8 countries.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-transtatsjp_199-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-transtatsjp-199">
        [199]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Since privatisation in 1987,
      <a href="/wiki/List_of_railway_companies_in_Japan" title="List of railway companies in Japan">
       dozens of Japanese railway companies
      </a>
      compete in regional and local passenger transportation markets; major companies include seven
      <a href="/wiki/Japan_Railways_Group" title="Japan Railways Group">
       JR
      </a>
      enterprises,
      <a href="/wiki/Kintetsu_Railway" title="Kintetsu Railway">
       Kintetsu
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Seibu_Railway" title="Seibu Railway">
       Seibu Railway
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Keio_Corporation" title="Keio Corporation">
       Keio Corporation
      </a>
      . Some 250 high-speed
      <a href="/wiki/Shinkansen" title="Shinkansen">
       Shinkansen
      </a>
      trains connect major cities and Japanese trains are known for their safety and punctuality.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-200">
       <a href="#cite_note-200">
        [200]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-201">
       <a href="#cite_note-201">
        [201]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Proposals for a new
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/JR%E2%80%93Maglev" title="JR–Maglev">
       Maglev
      </a>
      route between Tokyo and Osaka are at an advanced stage.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-202">
       <a href="#cite_note-202">
        [202]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      There are 175 airports in Japan;
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cia_2-5">
       <a href="#cite_note-cia-2">
        [2]
       </a>
      </sup>
      the largest domestic airport,
      <a href="/wiki/Haneda_Airport" title="Haneda Airport">
       Haneda Airport
      </a>
      , is
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/World%27s_busiest_airports_by_passenger_traffic" title="World's busiest airports by passenger traffic">
       Asia's second-busiest airport
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-203">
       <a href="#cite_note-203">
        [203]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The largest international gateways are
      <a href="/wiki/Narita_International_Airport" title="Narita International Airport">
       Narita International Airport
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Kansai_International_Airport" title="Kansai International Airport">
       Kansai International Airport
      </a>
      and
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ch%C5%ABbu_Centrair_International_Airport" title="Chūbu Centrair International Airport">
       Chūbu Centrair International Airport
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-204">
       <a href="#cite_note-204">
        [204]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Nagoya_Port" title="Nagoya Port">
       Nagoya Port
      </a>
      is the country's largest and busiest port, accounting for 10 percent of Japan's trade value.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-205">
       <a href="#cite_note-205">
        [205]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Energy">
       Energy
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Main article:
      <a href="/wiki/Energy_in_Japan" title="Energy in Japan">
       Energy in Japan
      </a>
     </div>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Kashiwazaki_Kariwa-April_2011.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="768" data-file-width="1024" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/24/Kashiwazaki_Kariwa-April_2011.jpg/220px-Kashiwazaki_Kariwa-April_2011.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/24/Kashiwazaki_Kariwa-April_2011.jpg/330px-Kashiwazaki_Kariwa-April_2011.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/24/Kashiwazaki_Kariwa-April_2011.jpg/440px-Kashiwazaki_Kariwa-April_2011.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Kashiwazaki_Kariwa-April_2011.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        The
        <a href="/wiki/Kashiwazaki-Kariwa_Nuclear_Power_Plant" title="Kashiwazaki-Kariwa Nuclear Power Plant">
         Kashiwazaki-Kariwa Nuclear Power Plant
        </a>
        , a nuclear plant with seven units, the largest single nuclear power station in the world
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      As of 2011
      <sup class="plainlinks noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;">
       <a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Japan&amp;action=edit">
        [update]
       </a>
      </sup>
      , 46.1% of energy in Japan was produced from petroleum, 21.3% from coal, 21.4% from natural gas, 4.0% from
      <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_power_in_Japan" title="Nuclear power in Japan">
       nuclear power
      </a>
      , and 3.3% from
      <a href="/wiki/Hydropower" title="Hydropower">
       hydropower
      </a>
      . Nuclear power produced 9.2 percent of Japan's electricity, as of 2011
      <sup class="plainlinks noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;">
       <a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Japan&amp;action=edit">
        [update]
       </a>
      </sup>
      , down from 24.9 percent the previous year.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-206">
       <a href="#cite_note-206">
        [206]
       </a>
      </sup>
      However, by May 2012 all of the country's nuclear power plants had been taken offline because of ongoing public opposition following the
      <a href="/wiki/Fukushima_Daiichi_nuclear_disaster" title="Fukushima Daiichi nuclear disaster">
       Fukushima Daiichi nuclear disaster
      </a>
      in March 2011, though government officials continued to try to sway public opinion in favor of returning at least some of Japan's 50 nuclear reactors to service.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-207">
       <a href="#cite_note-207">
        [207]
       </a>
      </sup>
      As of November 2014
      <sup class="plainlinks noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;">
       <a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Japan&amp;action=edit">
        [update]
       </a>
      </sup>
      , two reactors at Sendai are likely to restart in early 2015.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-208">
       <a href="#cite_note-208">
        [208]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Japan lacks significant domestic reserves and so has a heavy dependence on
      <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_oil_imports" title="List of countries by oil imports">
       imported energy
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-209">
       <a href="#cite_note-209">
        [209]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Japan has therefore aimed to diversify its sources and maintain high levels of energy efficiency.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-210">
       <a href="#cite_note-210">
        [210]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Water_supply_and_sanitation">
       Water supply and sanitation
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Main article:
      <a href="/wiki/Water_supply_and_sanitation_in_Japan" title="Water supply and sanitation in Japan">
       Water supply and sanitation in Japan
      </a>
     </div>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Tokuyama_Dam.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3072" data-file-width="2304" height="293" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/61/Tokuyama_Dam.jpg/220px-Tokuyama_Dam.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/61/Tokuyama_Dam.jpg/330px-Tokuyama_Dam.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/61/Tokuyama_Dam.jpg/440px-Tokuyama_Dam.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Tokuyama_Dam.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        <a href="/wiki/Tokuyama_Dam" title="Tokuyama Dam">
         Tokuyama Dam
        </a>
        in
        <a href="/wiki/Gifu_Prefecture" title="Gifu Prefecture">
         Gifu Prefecture
        </a>
        is the largest dam in Japan
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      The government took responsibility for regulating the water and sanitation sector is shared between the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Health,_Labour_and_Welfare_(Japan)" title="Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare (Japan)">
       Ministry of Health, Labor and Welfare
      </a>
      in charge of water supply for domestic use; the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Land,_Infrastructure,_Transport_and_Tourism_(Japan)" title="Ministry of Land, Infrastructure, Transport and Tourism (Japan)">
       Ministry of Land, Infrastructure, Transport and Tourism
      </a>
      in charge of water resources development as well as sanitation; the
      <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_the_Environment_(Japan)" title="Ministry of the Environment (Japan)">
       Ministry of the Environment
      </a>
      in charge of ambient water quality and environmental preservation; and the
      <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Internal_Affairs_and_Communications" title="Ministry of Internal Affairs and Communications">
       Ministry of Internal Affairs and Communications
      </a>
      in charge of performance benchmarking of utilities.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-211">
       <a href="#cite_note-211">
        [211]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Access to an
      <a href="/wiki/Improved_water_source" title="Improved water source">
       improved water source
      </a>
      is universal in Japan. 97% of the population receives piped water supply from public utilities and 3% receive water from their own wells or unregulated small systems, mainly in rural areas.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-212">
       <a href="#cite_note-212">
        [212]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Access to
      <a href="/wiki/Improved_sanitation" title="Improved sanitation">
       improved sanitation
      </a>
      is also universal, either through sewers or on-site sanitation. All collected waste water is treated at secondary-level treatment plants. All effluents discharged to closed or semi-closed water bodies, such as
      <a href="/wiki/Tokyo_Bay" title="Tokyo Bay">
       Tokyo Bay
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Osaka_Bay" title="Osaka Bay">
       Osaka Bay
      </a>
      , or
      <a href="/wiki/Lake_Biwa" title="Lake Biwa">
       Lake Biwa
      </a>
      , are further treated to tertiary level. This applies to about 15% of waste water. The effluent quality is remarkably good at 3–10 mg/l of
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Biological_Oxygen_Demand" title="Biological Oxygen Demand">
       BOD
      </a>
      for secondary-level treatment, well below the national effluent standard of 20 mg/l.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ueda_213-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Ueda-213">
        [213]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Water supply and sanitation in Japan is facing some challenges, such as a decreasing population, declining investment, fiscal constraints, ageing facilities, an ageing workforce, a fragmentation of service provision among thousands of municipal utilities, and the vulnerability of parts of the country to droughts that are expected to become more frequent due to climate change.
     </p>
     <h2>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Demographics">
       Demographics
      </span>
     </h2>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Main articles:
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Demographics_of_Japan" title="Demographics of Japan">
       Demographics of Japan
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Japanese_people" title="Japanese people">
       Japanese people
      </a>
      , and
      <a href="/wiki/Ethnic_issues_in_Japan" title="Ethnic issues in Japan">
       Ethnic issues in Japan
      </a>
     </div>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Bjs48_02_Ainu.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="338" data-file-width="507" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9b/Bjs48_02_Ainu.jpg/220px-Bjs48_02_Ainu.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9b/Bjs48_02_Ainu.jpg/330px-Bjs48_02_Ainu.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9b/Bjs48_02_Ainu.jpg/440px-Bjs48_02_Ainu.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Bjs48_02_Ainu.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        <a href="/wiki/Ainu_people" title="Ainu people">
         Ainu
        </a>
        , an ethnic minority people from Japan
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Population">
       Population
      </span>
     </h3>
     <p>
      Japan's population is estimated at around 127 million,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cia_2-6">
       <a href="#cite_note-cia-2">
        [2]
       </a>
      </sup>
      with 80% of the population living on
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Honsh%C5%AB" title="Honshū">
       Honshū
      </a>
      . Japanese society is
      <a href="/wiki/Linguistics" title="Linguistics">
       linguistically
      </a>
      and culturally homogeneous,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MulticulturalJapan_214-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-MulticulturalJapan-214">
        [214]
       </a>
      </sup>
      composed of 98.5% ethnic Japanese,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cia_2-7">
       <a href="#cite_note-cia-2">
        [2]
       </a>
      </sup>
      with small populations of foreign workers.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MulticulturalJapan_214-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-MulticulturalJapan-214">
        [214]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <a href="/wiki/Koreans_in_Japan" title="Koreans in Japan">
       Zainichi Koreans
      </a>
      ,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-215">
       <a href="#cite_note-215">
        [215]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <a href="/wiki/Chinese_people_in_Japan" title="Chinese people in Japan">
       Chinese
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Filipinos_in_Japan" title="Filipinos in Japan">
       Filipinos
      </a>
      ,
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Brazilian_people" title="Brazilian people">
       Brazilians
      </a>
      mostly
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Japanese_Brazilian" title="Japanese Brazilian">
       of Japanese descent
      </a>
      ,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-nikkeijin_216-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-nikkeijin-216">
        [216]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Peruvian_people" title="Peruvian people">
       Peruvians
      </a>
      mostly
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Japanese_Peruvian" title="Japanese Peruvian">
       of Japanese descent
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Americans_in_Japan" title="Americans in Japan">
       Americans
      </a>
      are among the small minority groups in Japan.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-217">
       <a href="#cite_note-217">
        [217]
       </a>
      </sup>
      In 2003, there were about 134,700 non-Latin American Western (not including more than 33,000
      <a href="/wiki/United_States_Forces_Japan" title="United States Forces Japan">
       American military personnel
      </a>
      and their dependents stationed throughout the country)
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-218">
       <a href="#cite_note-218">
        [218]
       </a>
      </sup>
      and 345,500
      <a href="/wiki/Latin_Americans" title="Latin Americans">
       Latin American
      </a>
      expatriates, 274,700 of whom were
      <a href="/wiki/Brazilians_in_Japan" title="Brazilians in Japan">
       Brazilians
      </a>
      (said to be primarily Japanese descendants, or
      <i>
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Nikkeijin" title="Nikkeijin">
        nikkeijin
       </a>
      </i>
      , along with their spouses),
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-nikkeijin_216-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-nikkeijin-216">
        [216]
       </a>
      </sup>
      the largest community of Westerners.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-219">
       <a href="#cite_note-219">
        [219]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      The most dominant native ethnic group is the
      <a href="/wiki/Yamato_people" title="Yamato people">
       Yamato people
      </a>
      ; primary minority groups include the indigenous
      <a href="/wiki/Ainu_people" title="Ainu people">
       Ainu
      </a>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-220">
       <a href="#cite_note-220">
        [220]
       </a>
      </sup>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Ryukyuan_people" title="Ryukyuan people">
       Ryukyuan peoples
      </a>
      , as well as social minority groups like the
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Burakumin" title="Burakumin">
        burakumin
       </a>
      </i>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-221">
       <a href="#cite_note-221">
        [221]
       </a>
      </sup>
      There are persons of mixed ancestry incorporated among the Yamato, such as those from
      <a href="/wiki/Bonin_Islands" title="Bonin Islands">
       Ogasawara Archipelago
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-mccormack1999_222-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-mccormack1999-222">
        [222]
       </a>
      </sup>
      In 2014, foreign-born non-naturalized workers made up only 1.5% of the total population.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-223">
       <a href="#cite_note-223">
        [223]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Japan is widely regarded as ethnically homogeneous, and does not compile ethnicity or race statistics for Japanese nationals; however, at least one analysis describes Japan as a
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Multiethnic_society" title="Multiethnic society">
       multiethnic society
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-224">
       <a href="#cite_note-224">
        [224]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Most Japanese continue to see Japan as a
      <a href="/wiki/Monoculturalism" title="Monoculturalism">
       monocultural society
      </a>
      . Former Japanese Prime Minister and current Finance Minister
      <a href="/wiki/Tar%C5%8D_As%C5%8D" title="Tarō Asō">
       Tarō Asō
      </a>
      described Japan as being a nation of "one race, one civilization, one language and one culture", which drew criticism from representatives of ethnic minorities such as the
      <a href="/wiki/Ainu_people" title="Ainu people">
       Ainu
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-225">
       <a href="#cite_note-225">
        [225]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Japan has the second longest overall
      <a href="/wiki/Life_expectancy" title="Life expectancy">
       life expectancy
      </a>
      at birth of any country in the world: 83.5 years for persons born in the period 2010–2015.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Table_A.17_17-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-Table_A.17-17">
        [17]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-haaretz.com_226-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-haaretz.com-226">
        [226]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The
      <a href="/wiki/Aging_of_Japan" title="Aging of Japan">
       Japanese population is rapidly aging
      </a>
      as a result of a
      <a href="/wiki/Post%E2%80%93World_War_II_baby_boom" title="Post–World War II baby boom">
       post–World War II baby boom
      </a>
      followed by a decrease in birth rates. In 2012, about 24.1 percent of the population was over 65, and the proportion is projected to rise to almost 40 percent by 2050.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-handbook_227-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-handbook-227">
        [227]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <table class="navbox">
      <tr>
       <th class="navbox-title" colspan="10">
        <div style="float:right; width:6em; height:2.6em">
        </div>
        <div class="plainlinks hlist navbar mini" style="float: left;height:2.6em;">
         <ul>

            </abbr>
           </a>
          </li>
          <li class="nv-talk">

            </abbr>
           </a>
          </li>
          <li class="nv-edit">
           <a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Template:Largest_cities_of_Japan&amp;action=edit">
            <abbr title="Edit this template">
             e
            </abbr>
           </a>
          </li>
         </ul>
        </div>

          </a>

        </div>
