     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Religion">
       Religion
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Main article:
      <a href="/wiki/Religion_in_Japan" title="Religion in Japan">
       Religion in Japan
      </a>
     </div>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:200px">
       <div style="background-color:white;margin:auto;position:relative;width:200px;height:200px;overflow:hidden">
        <div class="transborder" style="position:absolute;width:100px;line-height:0;left:0; top:0; border-width:0 200px 200px 0; border-color:Black">
        </div>
        <div class="transborder" style="position:absolute;width:100px;line-height:0;left:100px; top:100px; border-width:100px 0 0 213.20584539969px; border-left-color:DodgerBlue">
        </div>
        <div style="position:absolute;line-height:0;border-style:solid;left:0;top:0;border-width:0 200px 100px 0;border-color:DodgerBlue">
        </div>
        <div style="position:absolute;line-height:0;border-style:solid;left:0;top:0;border-width:0 100px 200px 0;border-color:DodgerBlue">
        </div>
        <div class="transborder" style="position:absolute;width:100px;line-height:0;left:100px; top:100px; border-width:100px 0 0 151.61189335389px; border-left-color:GreenYellow">
        </div>
        <div style="position:absolute;line-height:0;border-style:solid;left:0;top:0;border-width:0 200px 100px 0;border-color:GreenYellow">
        </div>
        <div style="position:absolute;line-height:0;border-style:solid;left:0;top:0;border-width:0 100px 200px 0;border-color:GreenYellow">
        </div>
        <div class="transborder" style="position:absolute;width:100px;line-height:0;left:100px; top:100px; border-width:100px 0 0 90.649023674519px; border-left-color:Yellow">
        </div>
        <div style="position:absolute;line-height:0;border-style:solid;left:0;top:0;border-width:0 200px 100px 0;border-color:Yellow">
        </div>
        <div style="position:absolute;line-height:0;border-style:solid;left:0;top:0;border-width:0 100px 200px 0;border-color:Yellow">
        </div>
        <div class="transborder" style="position:absolute;width:100px;line-height:0;right:100px; top:100px; border-width:11.41049042345px 99.346870651754px 0 0; border-top-color:FireBrick">
        </div>
        <div style="position:absolute;line-height:0;border-style:solid;left:0;top:0;border-width:0 200px 100px 0;border-color:FireBrick">
        </div>
        <div style="position:absolute;left:0;top:0">
         <img alt="Circle frame.svg" data-file-height="200" data-file-width="200" height="200" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/18/Circle_frame.svg/200px-Circle_frame.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/18/Circle_frame.svg/300px-Circle_frame.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/18/Circle_frame.svg/400px-Circle_frame.svg.png 2x" width="200"/>
        </div>
       </div>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <p>
         Religion in Japan
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Dentsu2006_228-0">
          <a href="#cite_note-Dentsu2006-228">
           [228]
          </a>
         </sup>
        </p>
        <div class="legend">
         <span class="legend-color" style="display:inline-block; width:1.5em; height:1.5em; margin:1px 0; border:1px solid black; background-color:FireBrick; color:black; font-size:100%; text-align:center;">
         </span>
         Folk
         <a href="/wiki/Shinto" title="Shinto">
          Shinto
         </a>
         , or "not religious"
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-229">
          <a href="#cite_note-229">
           [note 1]
          </a>
         </sup>
         (51.82%)
        </div>
        <div class="legend">
         <span class="legend-color" style="display:inline-block; width:1.5em; height:1.5em; margin:1px 0; border:1px solid black; background-color:Yellow; color:black; font-size:100%; text-align:center;">
         </span>
         <a href="/wiki/Buddhism_in_Japan" title="Buddhism in Japan">
          Buddhism
         </a>
         (34.9%)
        </div>
        <div class="legend">
         <span class="legend-color" style="display:inline-block; width:1.5em; height:1.5em; margin:1px 0; border:1px solid black; background-color:GreenYellow; color:black; font-size:100%; text-align:center;">
         </span>
         <a href="/wiki/Shinto_sects_and_schools#Shint.C5.8D_inspired_religions" title="Shinto sects and schools">
          Shinto organisations and others
         </a>
         (4%)
        </div>
        <div class="legend">
         <span class="legend-color" style="display:inline-block; width:1.5em; height:1.5em; margin:1px 0; border:1px solid black; background-color:DodgerBlue; color:black; font-size:100%; text-align:center;">
         </span>
         <a href="/wiki/Christianity" title="Christianity">
          Christianity
         </a>
         (2.3%)
        </div>
        <div class="legend">
         <span class="legend-color" style="display:inline-block; width:1.5em; height:1.5em; margin:1px 0; border:1px solid black; background-color:Black; color:black; font-size:100%; text-align:center;">
         </span>
         No answer (6.98%)
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Itsukushima_torii_distance.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="684" data-file-width="966" height="156" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/07/Itsukushima_torii_distance.jpg/220px-Itsukushima_torii_distance.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/07/Itsukushima_torii_distance.jpg/330px-Itsukushima_torii_distance.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/07/Itsukushima_torii_distance.jpg/440px-Itsukushima_torii_distance.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Itsukushima_torii_distance.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        The
        <a href="/wiki/Torii" title="Torii">
         torii
        </a>
        of
        <a href="/wiki/Itsukushima_Shrine" title="Itsukushima Shrine">
         Itsukushima Shrine
        </a>
        near
        <a href="/wiki/Hiroshima" title="Hiroshima">
         Hiroshima
        </a>
        , one of the
        <a href="/wiki/Three_Views_of_Japan" title="Three Views of Japan">
         Three Views of Japan
        </a>
        and a UNESCO World Heritage Site
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      Japan has full religious freedom based on Article 20 of
      <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Japan" title="Constitution of Japan">
       its Constitution
      </a>
      . Upper estimates suggest that 84–96 percent of the Japanese population subscribe to
      <a href="/wiki/Shinto" title="Shinto">
       Shinto
      </a>
      as the indigenous religion which is as old as the Japanese people; or
      <a href="/wiki/Buddhism_in_Japan" title="Buddhism in Japan">
       Buddhism
      </a>
      was imported from the
      <a href="/wiki/Mainland_China" title="Mainland China">
       Mainland China
      </a>
      in the 6th century, including a large number of followers of a
      <a href="/wiki/Syncretism" title="Syncretism">
       syncretism
      </a>
      of
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Shinbutsu_sh%C5%ABg%C5%8D" title="Shinbutsu shūgō">
       both religions
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cia_2-8">
       <a href="#cite_note-cia-2">
        [2]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-230">
       <a href="#cite_note-230">
        [229]
       </a>
      </sup>
      However, these estimates are based on people
      <a href="/wiki/Danka_system" title="Danka system">
       affiliated
      </a>
      with a temple, rather than the number of true believers. Other studies have suggested that only 30 percent of the population identify themselves as belonging to a religion.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Kisala_231-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Kisala-231">
        [230]
       </a>
      </sup>
      According to
      <a href="/wiki/Edwin_O._Reischauer" title="Edwin O. Reischauer">
       Edwin Reischauer
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Marius_Jansen" title="Marius Jansen">
       Marius Jansen
      </a>
      , some 70–80% of the Japanese do not consider themselves believers in any religion. Nevertheless, the level of participation remains high, especially during
      <a href="/wiki/Japanese_festivals" title="Japanese festivals">
       festivals
      </a>
      and occasions such as the
      <a href="/wiki/Hatsum%C5%8Dde" title="Hatsumōde">
       first shrine visit
      </a>
      of the
      <a href="/wiki/Japanese_New_Year" title="Japanese New Year">
       New Year
      </a>
      .
      <a href="/wiki/Taoism" title="Taoism">
       Taoism
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Confucianism" title="Confucianism">
       Confucianism
      </a>
      from China have also influenced Japanese beliefs and customs.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-232">
       <a href="#cite_note-232">
        [231]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Japanese streets are decorated on
      <a href="/wiki/Tanabata" title="Tanabata">
       Tanabata
      </a>
      ,
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Obon" title="Obon">
       Obon
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Christmas" title="Christmas">
       Christmas
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ReischauerJansen215_233-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-ReischauerJansen215-233">
        [232]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      <a href="/wiki/Christianity" title="Christianity">
       Christianity
      </a>
      was first introduced into Japan by
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Jesuit" title="Jesuit">
       Jesuit
      </a>
      missions starting in 1549.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Higashibaba.2C_2002._p._1_234-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Higashibaba.2C_2002._p._1-234">
        [233]
       </a>
      </sup>
      These missionaries were successful in converting large numbers of people in Kyushu, including peasants, former Buddhist monks, and members of the warrior class.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Higashibaba.2C_2002._p._12_235-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Higashibaba.2C_2002._p._12-235">
        [234]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Near the end of the 16th century,
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Franciscan" title="Franciscan">
       Franciscan
      </a>
      missionaries arrived in Kyoto, despite a ban issued by
      <a href="/wiki/Toyotomi_Hideyoshi" title="Toyotomi Hideyoshi">
       Toyotomi Hideyoshi
      </a>
      . In 1597, Hideyoshi proclaimed a more serious edict and
      <a href="/wiki/Twenty-six_Martyrs_of_Japan" title="Twenty-six Martyrs of Japan">
       executed 26 Franciscans
      </a>
      in
      <a href="/wiki/Nagasaki" title="Nagasaki">
       Nagasaki
      </a>
      as a warning.
      <a href="/wiki/Tokugawa_Ieyasu" title="Tokugawa Ieyasu">
       Tokugawa Ieyasu
      </a>
      and his successors enforced the prohibition of Christianity with several further edicts, especially after the
      <a href="/wiki/Shimabara_Rebellion" title="Shimabara Rebellion">
       Shimabara Rebellion
      </a>
      in the 1630s. In 1873, following the
      <a href="/wiki/Meiji_Restoration" title="Meiji Restoration">
       Meiji Restoration
      </a>
      , the ban was rescinded,
      <a href="/wiki/Freedom_of_religion" title="Freedom of religion">
       freedom of religion
      </a>
      was promulgated, and
      <a href="/wiki/Protestantism" title="Protestantism">
       Protestant
      </a>
      missionaries (プロテスタント
      <i>
       Purotesutanto
      </i>
      or 新教
      <i>
       Shinkyō
      </i>
      , "renewed teaching") began to proselytise in Japan, intensifying their activities after
      <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">
       World War II
      </a>
      , yet they were never as successful as in
      <a href="/wiki/Religion_in_South_Korea" title="Religion in South Korea">
       Korea
      </a>
      . Today, there are 1 to 3 million Christians in Japan, most of them living in the western part of the country, where the missionaries' activities were greatest during the 16th century.
      <a href="/wiki/Nagasaki_Prefecture" title="Nagasaki Prefecture">
       Nagasaki Prefecture
      </a>
      has the highest percentage of Christians: about 5.1% in 1996.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-236">
       <a href="#cite_note-236">
        [235]
       </a>
      </sup>
      As of 2007 there are 32,036 Christian priests and pastors in Japan.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Bestor.2C_Yamagata._2011._p._65_237-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Bestor.2C_Yamagata._2011._p._65-237">
        [236]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Throughout the latest century, some Western customs originally related to Christianity (including
      <a href="/wiki/Marriage_in_Japan" title="Marriage in Japan">
       Western style weddings
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Valentine%27s_Day" title="Valentine's Day">
       Valentine's Day
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Christmas" title="Christmas">
       Christmas
      </a>
      ) have become popular as secular customs among many Japanese.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-238">
       <a href="#cite_note-238">
        [237]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      <a href="/wiki/Islam" title="Islam">
       Islam
      </a>
      in Japan is mostly represented by small immigrant communities from other parts of
      <a href="/wiki/Asia" title="Asia">
       Asia
      </a>
      . In 2008, Keiko Sakurai estimated that 80–90% of the Muslims in Japan were foreign born migrants primarily from
      <a href="/wiki/Indonesia" title="Indonesia">
       Indonesia
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Pakistan" title="Pakistan">
       Pakistan
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Bangladesh" title="Bangladesh">
       Bangladesh
      </a>
      , and
      <a href="/wiki/Iran" title="Iran">
       Iran
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-239">
       <a href="#cite_note-239">
        [238]
       </a>
      </sup>
      It has been estimated that the Muslim immigrant population amounts to 70,000–100,000 people, while the "estimated number of Japanese Muslims ranges from thousands to tens of thousands".
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-240">
       <a href="#cite_note-240">
        [239]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Other minority religions include
      <a href="/wiki/Hinduism_in_Japan" title="Hinduism in Japan">
       Hinduism
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Sikhism" title="Sikhism">
       Sikhism
      </a>
      , and
      <a href="/wiki/Judaism" title="Judaism">
       Judaism
      </a>
      , and since the mid-19th century numerous
      <a href="/wiki/Japanese_new_religions" title="Japanese new religions">
       new religious movements
      </a>
      have emerged in Japan.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Clarke_241-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Clarke-241">
        [240]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Languages">
       Languages
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Main articles:
      <a href="/wiki/Languages_of_Japan" title="Languages of Japan">
       Languages of Japan
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Japanese_language" title="Japanese language">
       Japanese language
      </a>
     </div>
     <p>
      More than 99 percent of the population speaks Japanese as their first language.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cia_2-9">
       <a href="#cite_note-cia-2">
        [2]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Japanese is an
      <a href="/wiki/Agglutinative_language" title="Agglutinative language">
       agglutinative language
      </a>
      distinguished by a system of
      <a href="/wiki/Honorific_speech_in_Japanese" title="Honorific speech in Japanese">
       honorifics
      </a>
      reflecting the hierarchical nature of Japanese society, with verb forms and particular vocabulary indicating the relative status of speaker and listener.
      <a href="/wiki/Japanese_writing_system" title="Japanese writing system">
       Japanese writing
      </a>
      uses
      <a href="/wiki/Kanji" title="Kanji">
       kanji
      </a>
      (
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Chinese_character" title="Chinese character">
       Chinese characters
      </a>
      ) and two sets of
      <a href="/wiki/Kana" title="Kana">
       kana
      </a>
      (
      <a href="/wiki/Syllabary" title="Syllabary">
       syllabaries
      </a>
      based on
      <a href="/wiki/Cursive_script_(East_Asia)" title="Cursive script (East Asia)">
       cursive script
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Radical_(Chinese_characters)" title="Radical (Chinese characters)">
       radical
      </a>
      of kanji), as well as the
      <a href="/wiki/Latin_alphabet" title="Latin alphabet">
       Latin alphabet
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Arabic_numerals" title="Arabic numerals">
       Arabic numerals
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-242">
       <a href="#cite_note-242">
        [241]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Besides Japanese, the
      <a href="/wiki/Ryukyuan_languages" title="Ryukyuan languages">
       Ryukyuan languages
      </a>
      (
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Amami_language" title="Amami language">
       Amami
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Kunigami_language" title="Kunigami language">
       Kunigami
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Okinawan_language" title="Okinawan language">
       Okinawan
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Miyako_language" title="Miyako language">
       Miyako
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Yaeyama_language" title="Yaeyama language">
       Yaeyama
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Yonaguni_language" title="Yonaguni language">
       Yonaguni
      </a>
      ), also part of the
      <a href="/wiki/Japonic_languages" title="Japonic languages">
       Japonic language family
      </a>
      , are spoken in the
      <a href="/wiki/Ryukyu_Islands" title="Ryukyu Islands">
       Ryukyu Islands
      </a>
      chain. Few children learn these languages,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-243">
       <a href="#cite_note-243">
        [242]
       </a>
      </sup>
      but in recent years the local governments have sought to increase awareness of the traditional languages. The
      <a href="/wiki/Okinawan_Japanese" title="Okinawan Japanese">
       Okinawan Japanese
      </a>
      dialect is also spoken in the region. The
      <a href="/wiki/Ainu_language" title="Ainu language">
       Ainu language
      </a>
      , which has no proven relationship to Japanese or any other language, is
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Moribund_language" title="Moribund language">
       moribund
      </a>
      , with only a few elderly native speakers remaining in Hokkaido.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-244">
       <a href="#cite_note-244">
        [243]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Public and private schools generally require students to take Japanese language classes as well as
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/English_language_education_in_Japan" title="English language education in Japan">
       English
      </a>
      language courses.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-245">
       <a href="#cite_note-245">
        [244]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ItaGiappone_246-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-ItaGiappone-246">
        [245]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Problems">
       Problems
      </span>
     </h3>
     <p>
      The changes in demographic structure have created a number of social issues, particularly a potential decline in workforce population and increase in the cost of social security benefits like the public pension plan.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-247">
       <a href="#cite_note-247">
        [246]
       </a>
      </sup>
      A growing number of younger Japanese are not marrying or remain childless.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ogawa_248-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Ogawa-248">
        [247]
       </a>
      </sup>
      In 2011, Japan's population dropped for a fifth year, falling by 204,000 people to 126.24 million people. This was the greatest decline since at least 1947, when comparable figures were first compiled.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-249">
       <a href="#cite_note-249">
        [248]
       </a>
      </sup>
      This decline was made worse by the
      <a href="/wiki/2011_T%C5%8Dhoku_earthquake_and_tsunami" title="2011 Tōhoku earthquake and tsunami">
       March 11 earthquake and tsunami
      </a>
      , which killed nearly 16,000 people with approximately another 2,600 still listed as missing as of 2014
      <sup class="plainlinks noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;">
       <a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Japan&amp;action=edit">
        [update]
       </a>
      </sup>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-250">
       <a href="#cite_note-250">
        [249]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Japan's population is expected to drop to 95 million by 2050;
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-handbook_227-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-handbook-227">
        [227]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-251">
       <a href="#cite_note-251">
        [250]
       </a>
      </sup>
      demographers and government planners are currently in a heated debate over how to cope with this problem.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ogawa_248-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-Ogawa-248">
        [247]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <a href="/wiki/Immigration" title="Immigration">
       Immigration
      </a>
      and birth incentives are sometimes suggested as a solution to provide younger workers to support the nation's aging population.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-252">
       <a href="#cite_note-252">
        [251]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-253">
       <a href="#cite_note-253">
        [252]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Japan accepts a steady flow of 15,000
      <i>
       new Japanese citizens
      </i>
      by
      <i>
       naturalization
      </i>
      (帰化) per year.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-254">
       <a href="#cite_note-254">
        [253]
       </a>
      </sup>
      According to the
      <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_High_Commissioner_for_Refugees" title="United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees">
       UNHCR
      </a>
      , in 2012 Japan accepted just 18 refugees for resettlement,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-255">
       <a href="#cite_note-255">
        [254]
       </a>
      </sup>
      while the US took in 76,000.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-256">
       <a href="#cite_note-256">
        [255]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Japan
      <a href="/wiki/Suicide_in_Japan" title="Suicide in Japan">
       suffers from a high suicide rate
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYT_257-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-NYT-257">
        [256]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Times_258-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Times-258">
        [257]
       </a>
      </sup>
      In 2009, the number of suicides exceeded 30,000 for the twelfth straight year.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-259">
       <a href="#cite_note-259">
        [258]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Suicide is the leading cause of death for people under 30.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ozawa-desilva_260-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-ozawa-desilva-260">
        [259]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h2>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Education">
       Education
      </span>
     </h2>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Main article:
      <a href="/wiki/Education_in_Japan" title="Education in Japan">
       Education in Japan
      </a>
     </div>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Tokyo_University_Entrance_Exam_Results_6.JPG">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1944" data-file-width="2592" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/57/Tokyo_University_Entrance_Exam_Results_6.JPG/220px-Tokyo_University_Entrance_Exam_Results_6.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/57/Tokyo_University_Entrance_Exam_Results_6.JPG/330px-Tokyo_University_Entrance_Exam_Results_6.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/57/Tokyo_University_Entrance_Exam_Results_6.JPG/440px-Tokyo_University_Entrance_Exam_Results_6.JPG 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Tokyo_University_Entrance_Exam_Results_6.JPG" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        Announcement of the results of the
        <a href="/wiki/Higher_education_in_Japan#University_entrance" title="Higher education in Japan">
         entrance examinations
        </a>
        to the
        <a href="/wiki/University_of_Tokyo" title="University of Tokyo">
         University of Tokyo
        </a>
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      Primary schools, secondary schools and universities were
      <a href="/wiki/Education_in_the_Empire_of_Japan" title="Education in the Empire of Japan">
       introduced
      </a>
      in 1872 as a result of the Meiji Restoration.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-261">
       <a href="#cite_note-261">
        [260]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Since 1947, compulsory education in Japan comprises
      <a href="/wiki/Elementary_schools_in_Japan" title="Elementary schools in Japan">
       elementary
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Secondary_education_in_Japan#Middle_school" title="Secondary education in Japan">
       middle school
      </a>
      , which together last for nine years (from age 6 to age 15). Almost all children continue their education at a three-year senior
      <a href="/wiki/Secondary_education_in_Japan" title="Secondary education in Japan">
       high school
      </a>
      .
     </p>
     <p>
      Japan's education system played a central part in the country's recovery and
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Japanese_post-war_economic_miracle" title="Japanese post-war economic miracle">
       rapid economic growth
      </a>
      in the decades following the end of
      <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">
       World War II
      </a>
      . After World War II, the
      <a href="/wiki/Fundamental_Law_of_Education" title="Fundamental Law of Education">
       Fundamental Law of Education
      </a>
      and the School Education Law were enacted. The latter law defined the school system that would be in effect for many decades: six years of
      <a href="/wiki/Primary_education" title="Primary education">
       elementary school
      </a>
      , three years of
      <a href="/wiki/Middle_school" title="Middle school">
       junior high school
      </a>
      , three years of high school, and two or four years of university. Starting in April 2016, various schools began the academic year with elementary school and junior high school integrated into one nine-year compulsory schooling program, in hopes to mitigate
      <a href="/wiki/School_bullying" title="School bullying">
       bullying
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Truancy" title="Truancy">
       truancy
      </a>
      ;
      <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Education,_Culture,_Sports,_Science_and_Technology" title="Ministry of Education, Culture, Sports, Science and Technology">
       MEXT
      </a>
      plans for this approach to be adopted nationwide in the coming years.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-262">
       <a href="#cite_note-262">
        [261]
       </a>
      </sup>
      In Japan, having a strong educational background greatly improves the likelihood of finding a job and earning enough money to support oneself. Highly educated individuals are less affected by unemployment trends as higher levels of educational attainment make an individual more attractive in the workforce. The lifetime earnings also increase with each level of education attained. Furthermore, skills needed in the modern 21st century labor market are becoming more knowledge-based and strong aptitude in science and mathematics are more strong predictors of employment prospects in Japan's highly technological economy.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-263">
       <a href="#cite_note-263">
        [262]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Japan is one of the top-performing
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/OECD" title="OECD">
       OECD
      </a>
      countries in reading literacy, maths and sciences with the average student scoring 540 and has one of the worlds highest-educated labor forces among OECD countries.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-264">
       <a href="#cite_note-264">
        [263]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The Japanese populace is well educated and its society highly values education as a platform for social mobility and for gaining employment in the country's competitive high-tech economy. The country's large pool of highly educated and skilled individuals is largely responsible for ushering Japan’s post-war
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Japanese_post-war_economic_miracle" title="Japanese post-war economic miracle">
       economic growth
      </a>
      . Tertiary-educated adults in Japan, particularly graduates in sciences and engineering benefit economically and socially from their education and skills in the country's high tech economy.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-265">
       <a href="#cite_note-265">
        [264]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Spending on education as a proportion of GDP is below the OECD average. Although expenditure per student is comparatively high in Japan, total expenditure relative to GDP remains small.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-266">
       <a href="#cite_note-266">
        [265]
       </a>
      </sup>
      In 2015, Japan’s public spending on education amounted to just 3.5 percent of its GDP, below the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/OECD" title="OECD">
       OECD
      </a>
      average of 4.7%.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-267">
       <a href="#cite_note-267">
        [266]
       </a>
      </sup>
      In 2014, the country ranked fourth for the percentage of 25- to 64-year-olds that have attained tertiary education with 48 percent. In addition, bachelor's degrees are held by 59 percent of Japanese aged 25–34, the second most in the OECD after South Korea.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-OECD_14-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-OECD-14">
        [14]
       </a>
      </sup>
      As the Japanese economy is largely scientific and technological based, the labor market demands people who have achieved some form of higher education, particularly related to science and engineering in order to gain a competitive edge when searching for employment opportunities. About 75.9 percent of high school graduates attended a university, junior college, trade school, or other
      <a href="/wiki/Higher_education_in_Japan" title="Higher education in Japan">
       higher education
      </a>
      institution.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-268">
       <a href="#cite_note-268">
        [267]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      The two top-ranking universities in Japan are the
      <a href="/wiki/University_of_Tokyo" title="University of Tokyo">
       University of Tokyo
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Kyoto_University" title="Kyoto University">
       Kyoto University
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-269">
       <a href="#cite_note-269">
        [268]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-270">
       <a href="#cite_note-270">
        [269]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The
      <a href="/wiki/Programme_for_International_Student_Assessment" title="Programme for International Student Assessment">
       Programme for International Student Assessment
      </a>
      coordinated by the OECD currently ranks the overall knowledge and skills of Japanese 15-year-olds as sixth best in the world.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-271">
       <a href="#cite_note-271">
        [270]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h2>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Health">
       Health
      </span>
     </h2>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Main articles:
      <a href="/wiki/Health_in_Japan" title="Health in Japan">
       Health in Japan
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Health_care_system_in_Japan" title="Health care system in Japan">
       Health care system in Japan
      </a>
     </div>
     <p>
      In Japan, health care is provided by national and local governments. Payment for personal medical services is offered through a universal health insurance system that provides relative equality of access, with fees set by a government committee. People without insurance through employers can participate in a national health insurance program administered by local governments. Since 1973, all elderly persons have been covered by government-sponsored insurance.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-272">
       <a href="#cite_note-272">
        [271]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Patients are free to select the physicians or facilities of their choice.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-273">
       <a href="#cite_note-273">
        [272]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h2>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Culture">
       Culture
      </span>
     </h2>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Main article:
      <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_Japan" title="Culture of Japan">
       Culture of Japan
      </a>
     </div>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      See also:
      <a href="/wiki/Japanese_popular_culture" title="Japanese popular culture">
       Japanese popular culture
      </a>
     </div>
     <table class="vertical-navbox nowraplinks hlist" style="float:right;clear:right;width:22.0em;margin:0 0 1.0em 1.0em;background:#f9f9f9;border:1px solid #aaa;padding:0.2em;border-spacing:0.4em 0;text-align:center;line-height:1.4em;font-size:88%">

        <ul>
         <li class="mw-empty-elt">
         </li>
         <li>
          <span class="metadata">
           <img alt="" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="600" data-file-width="900" height="11" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/9e/Flag_of_Japan.svg/16px-Flag_of_Japan.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/9e/Flag_of_Japan.svg/24px-Flag_of_Japan.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/9e/Flag_of_Japan.svg/32px-Flag_of_Japan.svg.png 2x" width="16"/>
