      <tr>
       <td style="text-align:right;font-size:115%;padding-top: 0.6em;">
        <div class="plainlinks hlist navbar mini">
         <ul>
          <li class="nv-view">
           <a href="/wiki/Template:Culture_of_Japan" title="Template:Culture of Japan">
            <abbr title="View this template">
             v
            </abbr>
           </a>
          </li>
          <li class="nv-talk">
           <a href="/wiki/Template_talk:Culture_of_Japan" title="Template talk:Culture of Japan">
            <abbr title="Discuss this template">
             t
            </abbr>
           </a>
          </li>
          <li class="nv-edit">
           <a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Template:Culture_of_Japan&amp;action=edit">
            <abbr title="Edit this template">
             e
            </abbr>
           </a>
          </li>
         </ul>
        </div>
       </td>
      </tr>
     </table>
     <p>
      Japanese culture has evolved greatly from its origins. Contemporary culture combines influences from Asia, Europe and North America. Traditional Japanese arts include
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Japanese_handicrafts" title="Japanese handicrafts">
       crafts
      </a>
      such as
      <a href="/wiki/Japanese_pottery_and_porcelain" title="Japanese pottery and porcelain">
       ceramics
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Kimono" title="Kimono">
       textiles
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Japanese_lacquerware" title="Japanese lacquerware">
       lacquerware
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Japanese_sword" title="Japanese sword">
       swords
      </a>
      and
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Japanese_traditional_dolls" title="Japanese traditional dolls">
       dolls
      </a>
      ; performances of
      <a href="/wiki/Bunraku" title="Bunraku">
       bunraku
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Kabuki" title="Kabuki">
       kabuki
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Noh" title="Noh">
       noh
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Japanese_traditional_dance" title="Japanese traditional dance">
       dance
      </a>
      , and
      <a href="/wiki/Rakugo" title="Rakugo">
       rakugo
      </a>
      ; and other practices, the
      <a href="/wiki/Japanese_tea_ceremony" title="Japanese tea ceremony">
       tea ceremony
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Ikebana" title="Ikebana">
       ikebana
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Japanese_martial_arts" title="Japanese martial arts">
       martial arts
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Japanese_calligraphy" title="Japanese calligraphy">
       calligraphy
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Origami" title="Origami">
       origami
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Onsen" title="Onsen">
       onsen
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Geisha" title="Geisha">
       Geisha
      </a>
      and
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_Japanese_games" title="List of Japanese games">
       games
      </a>
      . Japan has a developed system for the protection and promotion of both tangible and intangible
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cultural_Properties_of_Japan" title="Cultural Properties of Japan">
       Cultural Properties
      </a>
      and
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/National_Treasures_of_Japan" title="National Treasures of Japan">
       National Treasures
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-274">
       <a href="#cite_note-274">
        [273]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/World_Heritage_Sites_in_Japan" title="World Heritage Sites in Japan">
       Nineteen sites
      </a>
      have been inscribed on the UNESCO World Heritage List, fifteen of which are of cultural significance.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-unesco1_76-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-unesco1-76">
        [76]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Architecture">
       Architecture
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Main article:
      <a href="/wiki/Japanese_architecture" title="Japanese architecture">
       Japanese architecture
      </a>
     </div>
     <div class="thumb tleft">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Kinkaku-ji_01.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1827" data-file-width="2590" height="155" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f8/Kinkaku-ji_01.jpg/220px-Kinkaku-ji_01.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f8/Kinkaku-ji_01.jpg/330px-Kinkaku-ji_01.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f8/Kinkaku-ji_01.jpg/440px-Kinkaku-ji_01.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Kinkaku-ji_01.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        <a href="/wiki/Kinkaku-ji" title="Kinkaku-ji">
         Kinkaku-ji
        </a>
        or "The Temple of the Golden Pavilion" in
        <a href="/wiki/Historic_Monuments_of_Ancient_Kyoto_(Kyoto,_Uji_and_Otsu_Cities)" title="Historic Monuments of Ancient Kyoto (Kyoto, Uji and Otsu Cities)">
         Kyoto
        </a>
        ,
        <a href="/wiki/List_of_Special_Places_of_Scenic_Beauty,_Special_Historic_Sites_and_Special_Natural_Monuments" title="List of Special Places of Scenic Beauty, Special Historic Sites and Special Natural Monuments">
         Special Historic Site, Special Place of Scenic Beauty
        </a>
        , and a UNESCO World Heritage Site. Its torching by a monk in 1950 is the subject of a
        <a href="/wiki/The_Temple_of_the_Golden_Pavilion" title="The Temple of the Golden Pavilion">
         novel
        </a>
        by
        <a href="/wiki/Yukio_Mishima" title="Yukio Mishima">
         Mishima
        </a>
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      Japanese architecture is a great combination between local and other influences. It has traditionally been typified by wooden structures, elevated slightly off the ground, with tiled or thatched roofs. Sliding doors (
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Fusuma" title="Fusuma">
        fusuma
       </a>
      </i>
      ) were used in place of walls, allowing the internal configuration of a space to be customized for different occasions. People usually sat on cushions or otherwise on the floor, traditionally; chairs and high tables were not widely used until the 20th century. Since the 19th century, however, Japan has incorporated much of Western,
      <a href="/wiki/Modern_architecture" title="Modern architecture">
       modern
      </a>
      , and
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Post-modern_architecture" title="Post-modern architecture">
       post-modern
      </a>
      architecture into construction and design, and is today a leader in cutting-edge architectural design and technology.
     </p>
     <p>
      The introduction of
      <a href="/wiki/Buddhism_in_Japan" title="Buddhism in Japan">
       Buddhism
      </a>
      during the sixth century was a catalyst for large-scale
      <a href="/wiki/Buddhist_temples_in_Japan" title="Buddhist temples in Japan">
       temple
      </a>
      building using complicated techniques in wood. Influence from the Chinese
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Tang_Dynasty" title="Tang Dynasty">
       Tang
      </a>
      and
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sui_Dynasty" title="Sui Dynasty">
       Sui
      </a>
      Dynasties led to the foundation of the first permanent capital in
      <a href="/wiki/Nara,_Nara" title="Nara, Nara">
       Nara
      </a>
      . Its checkerboard street layout used the Chinese capital of
      <a href="/wiki/Chang%27an" title="Chang'an">
       Chang'an
      </a>
      as a template for its design. A gradual increase in the size of buildings led to standard units of measurement as well as refinements in layout and garden design. The introduction of the
      <a href="/wiki/Japanese_tea_ceremony" title="Japanese tea ceremony">
       tea ceremony
      </a>
      emphasised simplicity and modest design as a counterpoint to the excesses of the aristocracy.
     </p>
     <p>
      During the
      <a href="/wiki/Meiji_Restoration" title="Meiji Restoration">
       Meiji Restoration
      </a>
      of 1868 the history of Japanese architecture was radically changed by two important events. The first was the
      <a href="/wiki/Shinbutsu_bunri" title="Shinbutsu bunri">
       Kami and Buddhas Separation Act
      </a>
      of 1868, which formally separated Buddhism from
      <a href="/wiki/Shinto" title="Shinto">
       Shinto
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Buddhist_temples_in_Japan" title="Buddhist temples in Japan">
       Buddhist temples
      </a>
      from
      <a href="/wiki/Shinto_shrine" title="Shinto shrine">
       Shinto shrines
      </a>
      , breaking an association between the two which had lasted well over a thousand years.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-275">
       <a href="#cite_note-275">
        [274]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Second, it was then that Japan underwent a period of intense
      <a href="/wiki/Westernization" title="Westernization">
       Westernization
      </a>
      in order to compete with other developed countries. Initially architects and styles from abroad were imported to Japan but gradually the country taught its own architects and began to express its own style. Architects returning from study with western architects introduced the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/International_style_(architecture)" title="International style (architecture)">
       International Style
      </a>
      of modernism into Japan. However, it was not until after the Second World War that Japanese architects made an impression on the international scene, firstly with the work of architects like
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Kenzo_Tange" title="Kenzo Tange">
       Kenzo Tange
      </a>
      and then with theoretical movements like
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Metabolist_Movement" title="Metabolist Movement">
       Metabolism
      </a>
      .
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Art">
       Art
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Further information:
      <a href="/wiki/Japanese_art" title="Japanese art">
       Japanese art
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Japanese_garden" title="Japanese garden">
       Japanese garden
      </a>
      , and
      <a href="/wiki/Japanese_aesthetics" title="Japanese aesthetics">
       Japanese aesthetics
      </a>
     </div>
     <p>
      The
      <a href="/wiki/Ise_Grand_Shrine" title="Ise Grand Shrine">
       Shrines of Ise
      </a>
      have been celebrated as the prototype of Japanese architecture.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-276">
       <a href="#cite_note-276">
        [275]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Largely of wood,
      <a href="/wiki/Minka" title="Minka">
       traditional housing
      </a>
      and many
      <a href="/wiki/Japanese_Buddhist_architecture" title="Japanese Buddhist architecture">
       temple buildings
      </a>
      see the use of
      <a href="/wiki/Tatami" title="Tatami">
       tatami
      </a>
      mats and
      <a href="/wiki/Sh%C5%8Dji" title="Shōji">
       sliding doors
      </a>
      that break down the distinction between rooms and indoor and outdoor space.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-277">
       <a href="#cite_note-277">
        [276]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <a href="/wiki/Japanese_sculpture" title="Japanese sculpture">
       Japanese sculpture
      </a>
      , largely of wood, and
      <a href="/wiki/Japanese_painting" title="Japanese painting">
       Japanese painting
      </a>
      are among the oldest of the Japanese arts, with early figurative paintings dating back to at least 300 BC. The history of Japanese painting exhibits synthesis and competition between native
      <a href="/wiki/Japanese_aesthetics" title="Japanese aesthetics">
       Japanese aesthetics
      </a>
      and adaptation of imported ideas.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-autogenerated3_278-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-autogenerated3-278">
        [277]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      The interaction between Japanese and European art has been significant: for example
      <a href="/wiki/Ukiyo-e" title="Ukiyo-e">
       ukiyo-e
      </a>
      prints, which began to be exported in the 19th century in the movement known as
      <a href="/wiki/Japonism" title="Japonism">
       Japonism
      </a>
      , had a significant influence on the development of modern art in the West, most notably on
      <a href="/wiki/Post-Impressionism" title="Post-Impressionism">
       post-Impressionism
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-autogenerated3_278-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-autogenerated3-278">
        [277]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Famous ukiyo-e artists include
      <a href="/wiki/Hokusai" title="Hokusai">
       Hokusai
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Hiroshige" title="Hiroshige">
       Hiroshige
      </a>
      . Hokusai coined the term
      <a href="/wiki/Manga" title="Manga">
       manga
      </a>
      . Japanese comics now known as manga developed in the 20th century and have become popular worldwide.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-279">
       <a href="#cite_note-279">
        [278]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Japanese animation is called
      <a href="/wiki/Anime" title="Anime">
       anime
      </a>
      . Japanese-made
      <a href="/wiki/Video_game_console" title="Video game console">
       video game consoles
      </a>
      have been popular since the 1980s.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-280">
       <a href="#cite_note-280">
        [279]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <ul class="gallery mw-gallery-traditional">
      <li class="gallerybox" style="width: 235px">
       <div style="width: 235px">
        <div class="thumb" style="width: 230px;">
         <div style="margin:23.5px auto;">
          <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:HIRADO_PORCELAIN_CENSER_AND_COVER.JPG">
           <img alt="" data-file-height="2056" data-file-width="3088" height="133" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/21/HIRADO_PORCELAIN_CENSER_AND_COVER.JPG/200px-HIRADO_PORCELAIN_CENSER_AND_COVER.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/21/HIRADO_PORCELAIN_CENSER_AND_COVER.JPG/300px-HIRADO_PORCELAIN_CENSER_AND_COVER.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/21/HIRADO_PORCELAIN_CENSER_AND_COVER.JPG/400px-HIRADO_PORCELAIN_CENSER_AND_COVER.JPG 2x" width="200"/>
          </a>
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="gallerytext">
         <p>
          Hirado ware porcelain censers in the form of tiger and figurine with fan, brown and blue glazes
         </p>
        </div>
       </div>
      </li>
      <li class="gallerybox" style="width: 235px">
       <div style="width: 235px">
        <div class="thumb" style="width: 230px;">
         <div style="margin:21px auto;">
          <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:The_Great_Wave_off_Kanagawa.jpg">
           <img alt="" data-file-height="2990" data-file-width="4335" height="138" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0a/The_Great_Wave_off_Kanagawa.jpg/200px-The_Great_Wave_off_Kanagawa.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0a/The_Great_Wave_off_Kanagawa.jpg/300px-The_Great_Wave_off_Kanagawa.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0a/The_Great_Wave_off_Kanagawa.jpg/400px-The_Great_Wave_off_Kanagawa.jpg 2x" width="200"/>
          </a>
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="gallerytext">
         <p>
          19th-century
          <a href="/wiki/Ukiyo-e" title="Ukiyo-e">
           ukiyo-e
          </a>
          <a href="/wiki/Woodblock_printing_in_Japan" title="Woodblock printing in Japan">
           woodblock print
          </a>
          <i>
           <a href="/wiki/The_Great_Wave_off_Kanagawa" title="The Great Wave off Kanagawa">
            The Great Wave off Kanagawa
           </a>
          </i>
          , one of the best-recognized works of Japanese art in the world
         </p>
        </div>
       </div>
      </li>
      <li class="gallerybox" style="width: 235px">
       <div style="width: 235px">
        <div class="thumb" style="width: 230px;">
         <div style="margin:33.5px auto;">
          <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Japanese-Calligraphy-art.jpg">
           <img alt="" data-file-height="1080" data-file-width="1920" height="113" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/ba/Japanese-Calligraphy-art.jpg/200px-Japanese-Calligraphy-art.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/ba/Japanese-Calligraphy-art.jpg/300px-Japanese-Calligraphy-art.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/ba/Japanese-Calligraphy-art.jpg/400px-Japanese-Calligraphy-art.jpg 2x" width="200"/>
          </a>
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="gallerytext">
         <p>
          Example of
          <a href="/wiki/Japanese_calligraphy" title="Japanese calligraphy">
           Japanese calligraphy
          </a>
          (書道
          <i>
           shodō
          </i>
          )
         </p>
        </div>
       </div>
      </li>
      <li class="gallerybox" style="width: 235px">
       <div style="width: 235px">
        <div class="thumb" style="width: 230px;">
         <div style="margin:25.5px auto;">
          <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Anime-Store-In-Akihabara.jpg">
           <img alt="" data-file-height="670" data-file-width="1036" height="129" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/71/Anime-Store-In-Akihabara.jpg/200px-Anime-Store-In-Akihabara.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/71/Anime-Store-In-Akihabara.jpg/300px-Anime-Store-In-Akihabara.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/71/Anime-Store-In-Akihabara.jpg/400px-Anime-Store-In-Akihabara.jpg 2x" width="200"/>
          </a>
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="gallerytext">
         <p>
          An
          <a href="/wiki/Anime" title="Anime">
           anime
          </a>
          store in
          <a href="/wiki/Akihabara" title="Akihabara">
           Akihabara
          </a>
          ,
          <a href="/wiki/Tokyo" title="Tokyo">
           Tokyo
          </a>
          . Anime is a Japanese
          <a href="/wiki/Postmodern_art" title="Postmodern art">
           Postmodern art
          </a>
          which is usually made by hand-drawn or computer
          <a href="/wiki/Animation" title="Animation">
           animation
          </a>
         </p>
        </div>
       </div>
      </li>
     </ul>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Music">
       Music
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Main article:
      <a href="/wiki/Music_of_Japan" title="Music of Japan">
       Music of Japan
      </a>
     </div>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:KotoPlayer.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="195" data-file-width="300" height="143" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/36/KotoPlayer.jpg/220px-KotoPlayer.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/3/36/KotoPlayer.jpg 1.5x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:KotoPlayer.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        Masayo Ishigure playing 13-strings
        <a class="mw-disambig" href="/wiki/Koto" title="Koto">
         Koto
        </a>
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      Japanese music is eclectic and diverse. Many
      <a href="/wiki/Traditional_Japanese_musical_instruments" title="Traditional Japanese musical instruments">
       instruments
      </a>
      , such as the
      <a href="/wiki/Koto_(instrument)" title="Koto (instrument)">
       koto
      </a>
      , were introduced in the 9th and 10th centuries. The accompanied
      <a href="/wiki/Recitative" title="Recitative">
       recitative
      </a>
      of the
      <a href="/wiki/Noh" title="Noh">
       Noh
      </a>
      drama dates from the 14th century and the popular
      <a href="/wiki/Music_of_Japan#Folk_music" title="Music of Japan">
       folk music
      </a>
      , with the guitar-like
      <a href="/wiki/Shamisen" title="Shamisen">
       shamisen
      </a>
      , from the sixteenth.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-281">
       <a href="#cite_note-281">
        [280]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Western classical music, introduced in the late 19th century, now forms an integral part of Japanese culture. The imperial court ensemble
      <a href="/wiki/Gagaku" title="Gagaku">
       Gagaku
      </a>
      has influenced the work of some
      <a href="/wiki/20th-century_classical_music" title="20th-century classical music">
       modern
      </a>
      Western composers.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-282">
       <a href="#cite_note-282">
        [281]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Notable classical composers from Japan include
      <a href="/wiki/Toru_Takemitsu" title="Toru Takemitsu">
       Toru Takemitsu
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Rentar%C5%8D_Taki" title="Rentarō Taki">
       Rentarō Taki
      </a>
      . Popular music in post-war Japan has been heavily influenced by American and European trends, which has led to the evolution of
      <a href="/wiki/J-pop" title="J-pop">
       J-pop
      </a>
      , or Japanese popular music.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-283">
       <a href="#cite_note-283">
        [282]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <a href="/wiki/Karaoke" title="Karaoke">
       Karaoke
      </a>
      is the most widely practiced cultural activity in Japan. A 1993 survey by the
      <a href="/wiki/Agency_for_Cultural_Affairs" title="Agency for Cultural Affairs">
       Cultural Affairs Agency
      </a>
      found that more Japanese had sung karaoke that year than had participated in traditional pursuits such as flower arranging (ikebana) or tea ceremonies.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-284">
       <a href="#cite_note-284">
        [283]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Literature">
       Literature
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Main articles:
      <a href="/wiki/Japanese_literature" title="Japanese literature">
       Japanese literature
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Japanese_poetry" title="Japanese poetry">
       Japanese poetry
      </a>
     </div>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Genji_emaki_01003_001.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="243" data-file-width="517" height="103" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/69/Genji_emaki_01003_001.jpg/220px-Genji_emaki_01003_001.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/69/Genji_emaki_01003_001.jpg/330px-Genji_emaki_01003_001.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/69/Genji_emaki_01003_001.jpg/440px-Genji_emaki_01003_001.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Genji_emaki_01003_001.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        12th-century
        <a href="/wiki/Genji_Monogatari_Emaki" title="Genji Monogatari Emaki">
         illustrated handscroll
        </a>
        of
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/The_Tale_of_Genji" title="The Tale of Genji">
          The Tale of Genji
         </a>
        </i>
        , a
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/National_Treasures_of_Japan" title="National Treasures of Japan">
         National Treasure
        </a>
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      The earliest works of Japanese literature include the
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Kojiki" title="Kojiki">
        Kojiki
       </a>
      </i>
      and
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Nihon_Shoki" title="Nihon Shoki">
        Nihon Shoki
       </a>
      </i>
      chronicles and the
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Man%27y%C5%8Dsh%C5%AB" title="Man'yōshū">
        Man'yōshū
       </a>
      </i>
      <a href="/wiki/List_of_Japanese_poetry_anthologies" title="List of Japanese poetry anthologies">
       poetry anthology
      </a>
      , all from the 8th century and written in Chinese characters.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-285">
       <a href="#cite_note-285">
        [284]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-286">
       <a href="#cite_note-286">
        [285]
       </a>
      </sup>
      In the early Heian period, the system of
      <a href="/wiki/Phonogram_(linguistics)" title="Phonogram (linguistics)">
       phonograms
      </a>
      known as
      <i>
       kana
      </i>
      (
      <a href="/wiki/Hiragana" title="Hiragana">
       Hiragana
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Katakana" title="Katakana">
       Katakana
      </a>
      ) was developed.
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/The_Tale_of_the_Bamboo_Cutter" title="The Tale of the Bamboo Cutter">
        The Tale of the Bamboo Cutter
       </a>
      </i>
      is considered the oldest Japanese narrative.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ispmsu_287-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-ispmsu-287">
        [286]
       </a>
      </sup>
      An account of Heian court life is given in
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/The_Pillow_Book" title="The Pillow Book">
        The Pillow Book
       </a>
      </i>
      by
      <a href="/wiki/Sei_Sh%C5%8Dnagon" title="Sei Shōnagon">
       Sei Shōnagon
      </a>
      , while
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/The_Tale_of_Genji" title="The Tale of Genji">
        The Tale of Genji
       </a>
      </i>
      by
      <a href="/wiki/Murasaki_Shikibu" title="Murasaki Shikibu">
       Murasaki Shikibu
      </a>
      is often described as the world's first novel.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-288">
       <a href="#cite_note-288">
        [287]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-289">
       <a href="#cite_note-289">
        [288]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      During the Edo period, the
      <a href="/wiki/Ch%C5%8Dnin" title="Chōnin">
       chōnin
      </a>
      ("townspeople") overtook the samurai aristocracy as producers and consumers of literature. The popularity of the works of
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Saikaku" title="Saikaku">
       Saikaku
      </a>
      , for example, reveals this change in readership and authorship, while
      <a href="/wiki/Matsuo_Bash%C5%8D" title="Matsuo Bashō">
       Bashō
      </a>
      revivified the poetic tradition of the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Kokinsh%C5%AB" title="Kokinshū">
       Kokinshū
      </a>
      with his
      <a href="/wiki/Haikai" title="Haikai">
       haikai
      </a>
      (
      <a href="/wiki/Haiku" title="Haiku">
       haiku
      </a>
      ) and wrote the poetic travelogue
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Oku_no_Hosomichi" title="Oku no Hosomichi">
        Oku no Hosomichi
       </a>
      </i>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-290">
       <a href="#cite_note-290">
        [289]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The Meiji era saw the decline of traditional literary forms as Japanese literature integrated Western influences.
      <a href="/wiki/Natsume_S%C5%8Dseki" title="Natsume Sōseki">
       Natsume Sōseki
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Mori_%C5%8Cgai" title="Mori Ōgai">
       Mori Ōgai
      </a>
      were the first "modern" novelists of Japan, followed by
      <a href="/wiki/Ry%C5%ABnosuke_Akutagawa" title="Ryūnosuke Akutagawa">
       Ryūnosuke Akutagawa
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Jun%27ichir%C5%8D_Tanizaki" title="Jun'ichirō Tanizaki">
       Jun'ichirō Tanizaki
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Yukio_Mishima" title="Yukio Mishima">
       Yukio Mishima
      </a>
      and, more recently,
      <a href="/wiki/Haruki_Murakami" title="Haruki Murakami">
       Haruki Murakami
      </a>
      . Japan has two
      <a href="/wiki/Nobel_Prize_in_Literature" title="Nobel Prize in Literature">
       Nobel Prize-winning
      </a>
      authors—
      <a href="/wiki/Yasunari_Kawabata" title="Yasunari Kawabata">
       Yasunari Kawabata
      </a>
      (1968) and
      <a href="/wiki/Kenzabur%C5%8D_%C5%8Ce" title="Kenzaburō Ōe">
       Kenzaburō Ōe
      </a>
      (1994).
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ispmsu_287-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-ispmsu-287">
        [286]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Philosophy">
       Philosophy
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Main article:
      <a href="/wiki/Japanese_philosophy" title="Japanese philosophy">
       Japanese philosophy
      </a>
     </div>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Kitaro_Nishidain_in_Feb._1943.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="675" data-file-width="480" height="309" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e9/Kitaro_Nishidain_in_Feb._1943.jpg/220px-Kitaro_Nishidain_in_Feb._1943.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e9/Kitaro_Nishidain_in_Feb._1943.jpg/330px-Kitaro_Nishidain_in_Feb._1943.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e9/Kitaro_Nishidain_in_Feb._1943.jpg/440px-Kitaro_Nishidain_in_Feb._1943.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Kitaro_Nishidain_in_Feb._1943.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        <a href="/wiki/Kitaro_Nishida" title="Kitaro Nishida">
         Kitaro Nishida
        </a>
        , one of the most notable Japanese philosofer
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      Japanese Philosophy has historically been a
      <a class="mw-disambig" href="/wiki/Fusion" title="Fusion">
       fusion
      </a>
      of both foreign; particularly
      <a href="/wiki/Chinese_philosophy" title="Chinese philosophy">
       Chinese
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Western_philosophy" title="Western philosophy">
       Western
      </a>
      , and uniquely Japanese elements.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-291">
       <a href="#cite_note-291">
        [290]
       </a>
      </sup>
      In its literary forms, Japanese philosophy began about fourteen centuries ago.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-292">
       <a href="#cite_note-292">
        [291]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      <a href="/wiki/Archaeological_record" title="Archaeological record">
       Archaeological evidence
      </a>
      and early historical accounts suggest that Japan was originally an
      <a href="/wiki/Animism" title="Animism">
       animistic culture
      </a>
      , which viewed the world as infused with
      <i>
       kami
      </i>
      (神) or sacred presence as teached by
      <a href="/wiki/Shinto" title="Shinto">
       Shinto
      </a>
      , though its not a philosophy as such, but has greatly influenced all other philosophies in their Japanese interpretations.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-293">
       <a href="#cite_note-293">
        [292]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      <a href="/wiki/Confucianism" title="Confucianism">
       Confucianism
      </a>
      entered Japan from China around the 5th Century A.D., as did
      <a href="/wiki/Buddhism" title="Buddhism">
       Buddhism
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-294">
       <a href="#cite_note-294">
        [293]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Confucian ideals are still evident today in the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Japanese_society" title="Japanese society">
       Japanese concept of society
      </a>
      and the self, and in the organization of the
      <a href="/wiki/Government" title="Government">
       government
      </a>
      and the structure of
      <a href="/wiki/Society" title="Society">
       society
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-295">
       <a href="#cite_note-295">
        [294]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Buddhism has profoundly impacted Japanese psychology,
      <a href="/wiki/Metaphysics" title="Metaphysics">
       metaphysics
      </a>
      , and
      <a href="/wiki/Aesthetics" title="Aesthetics">
       aesthetics
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-296">
       <a href="#cite_note-296">
        [295]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      <a href="/wiki/Neo-Confucianism" title="Neo-Confucianism">
       Neo-Confucianism
      </a>
      which became prominent in the sixteenth century during the
      <a href="/wiki/Tokugawa_shogunate" title="Tokugawa shogunate">
       Tokugawa era
      </a>
      , shaped Japanese ideas of virtue and social responsibility; and through its emphasis on investigating the principle or configuration of things, stimulated the Japanese study of the natural world.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-297">
       <a href="#cite_note-297">
        [296]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Also since the 16th Century, certain indigenous ideas of
      <a href="/wiki/Loyalty" title="Loyalty">
       loyalty
      </a>
      and honour. Western philosophy has had its major impact in Japan only since the middle of the 19th Century.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-298">
       <a href="#cite_note-298">
        [297]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Cuisine">
       Cuisine
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Main article:
      <a href="/wiki/Japanese_cuisine" title="Japanese cuisine">
       Japanese cuisine
      </a>
     </div>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Breakfast_at_Tamahan_Ryokan,_Kyoto.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2004" data-file-width="3404" height="130" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f7/Breakfast_at_Tamahan_Ryokan%2C_Kyoto.jpg/220px-Breakfast_at_Tamahan_Ryokan%2C_Kyoto.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f7/Breakfast_at_Tamahan_Ryokan%2C_Kyoto.jpg/330px-Breakfast_at_Tamahan_Ryokan%2C_Kyoto.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f7/Breakfast_at_Tamahan_Ryokan%2C_Kyoto.jpg/440px-Breakfast_at_Tamahan_Ryokan%2C_Kyoto.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Breakfast_at_Tamahan_Ryokan,_Kyoto.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        Breakfast at a
        <i>
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ryokan_(Japanese_inn)" title="Ryokan (Japanese inn)">
          ryokan
         </a>
        </i>
        or inn
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      Japanese cuisine is based on combining
      <a href="/wiki/Staple_food" title="Staple food">
       staple foods
      </a>
      , typically
      <a href="/wiki/Japanese_rice" title="Japanese rice">
       Japanese rice
      </a>
      or
      <a href="/wiki/Japanese_noodles" title="Japanese noodles">
       noodles
      </a>
      , with a soup and
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Okazu" title="Okazu">
        okazu
       </a>
      </i>
      —dishes made from
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Fish_(food)" title="Fish (food)">
       fish
      </a>
      , vegetable,
      <a href="/wiki/Tofu" title="Tofu">
       tofu
      </a>
      and the like—to add flavor to the staple food. In the early modern era ingredients such as red meats that had previously not been widely used in Japan were introduced. Japanese cuisine is known for its emphasis on
      <a href="/wiki/Seasonal_food" title="Seasonal food">
       seasonality of food
      </a>
      ,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-299">
       <a href="#cite_note-299">
        [298]
       </a>
      </sup>
      quality of ingredients and presentation. Japanese cuisine offers a vast array of
      <a href="/wiki/Japanese_regional_cuisine" title="Japanese regional cuisine">
       regional specialties
      </a>
      that use traditional recipes and local ingredients. The phrase
      <i>
       ichijū-sansai
      </i>
      <span style="font-weight: normal">
       (
       <span class="t_nihongo_kanji" lang="ja">
        一汁三菜
       </span>
       <sup class="t_nihongo_help noprint">
        <a href="/wiki/Help:Installing_Japanese_character_sets" title="Help:Installing Japanese character sets">
         <span class="t_nihongo_icon" style="color: #00e; font: bold 80% sans-serif; text-decoration: none; padding: 0 .1em;">
          ?
         </span>
        </a>
       </sup>
       , "one soup, three sides")
      </span>
      refers to the makeup of a typical meal served, but has roots in classic
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Kaiseki" title="Kaiseki">
        kaiseki
       </a>
      </i>
      ,
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Honzen-ry%C5%8Dri" title="Honzen-ryōri">
        honzen
       </a>
       ,
      </i>
      and
      <i>
       yūsoku
      </i>
      cuisine. The term is also used to describe the first course served in standard
      <i>
       kaiseki
      </i>
      cuisine nowadays.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-yomiuri_300-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-yomiuri-300">
        [299]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Traditional Japanese sweets are known as
      <i>
       wagashi
      </i>
      . Ingredients such as
      <a href="/wiki/Red_bean_paste" title="Red bean paste">
       red bean paste
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Mochi" title="Mochi">
       mochi
      </a>
      are used. More modern-day tastes includes
      <a href="/wiki/Green_tea_ice_cream" title="Green tea ice cream">
       green tea ice cream
      </a>
      , a very popular flavor. Almost all manufacturers produce a version of it.
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Kakigori" title="Kakigori">
       Kakigori
      </a>
      is a shaved ice dessert flavored with syrup or condensed milk. It is usually sold and eaten at summer festivals. Popular Japanese beverages such as
      <a href="/wiki/Sake" title="Sake">
       sake
      </a>
      , which is a brewed rice beverage that, typically, contains 15%~17%
      <a href="/wiki/Ethanol" title="Ethanol">
       alcohol
      </a>
      and is made by multiple
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Fermentation_(food)" title="Fermentation (food)">
       fermentation
      </a>
      of rice. Other beverage like beer is produced in some region such as
      <a href="/wiki/Sapporo_Brewery" title="Sapporo Brewery">
       Sapporo Brewery
      </a>
      , the oldest Japan beer's brand. The
      <a href="/wiki/Michelin_Guide" title="Michelin Guide">
       Michelin Guide
      </a>
      has awarded restaurants in Japan more Michelin stars than the rest of the world combined.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-michelin20101124_301-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-michelin20101124-301">
        [300]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <ul class="gallery mw-gallery-traditional" style="text-align:center">
      <li class="gallerybox" style="width: 235px">
       <div style="width: 235px">
        <div class="thumb" style="width: 230px;">
         <div style="margin:33.5px auto;">
          <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:2007feb-sushi-odaiba-manytypes.jpg">
           <img alt="" data-file-height="1728" data-file-width="3072" height="113" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9c/2007feb-sushi-odaiba-manytypes.jpg/200px-2007feb-sushi-odaiba-manytypes.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9c/2007feb-sushi-odaiba-manytypes.jpg/300px-2007feb-sushi-odaiba-manytypes.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9c/2007feb-sushi-odaiba-manytypes.jpg/400px-2007feb-sushi-odaiba-manytypes.jpg 2x" width="200"/>
          </a>
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="gallerytext">
         <p>
          <a href="/wiki/Sushi" title="Sushi">
           Sushi
          </a>
          (寿司)
         </p>
        </div>
       </div>
      </li>
      <li class="gallerybox" style="width: 235px">
       <div style="width: 235px">
        <div class="thumb" style="width: 230px;">
         <div style="margin:15px auto;">
          <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Soy_ramen.jpg">
           <img alt="" data-file-height="600" data-file-width="800" height="150" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fc/Soy_ramen.jpg/200px-Soy_ramen.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fc/Soy_ramen.jpg/300px-Soy_ramen.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fc/Soy_ramen.jpg/400px-Soy_ramen.jpg 2x" width="200"/>
          </a>
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="gallerytext">
         <p>
          <a href="/wiki/Ramen" title="Ramen">
           Ramen
          </a>
          (ラーメン)
         </p>
        </div>
       </div>
      </li>
      <li class="gallerybox" style="width: 235px">
       <div style="width: 235px">
        <div class="thumb" style="width: 230px;">
         <div style="margin:33.5px auto;">
          <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Tempurainjapan-ikebukuro-dec312007.jpg">
           <img alt="" data-file-height="1728" data-file-width="3072" height="113" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0e/Tempurainjapan-ikebukuro-dec312007.jpg/200px-Tempurainjapan-ikebukuro-dec312007.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0e/Tempurainjapan-ikebukuro-dec312007.jpg/300px-Tempurainjapan-ikebukuro-dec312007.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0e/Tempurainjapan-ikebukuro-dec312007.jpg/400px-Tempurainjapan-ikebukuro-dec312007.jpg 2x" width="200"/>
          </a>
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="gallerytext">
         <p>
          <a href="/wiki/Tempura" title="Tempura">
           Tempura
          </a>
          (天ぷら)
         </p>
        </div>
       </div>
      </li>
      <li class="gallerybox" style="width: 235px">
       <div style="width: 235px">
        <div class="thumb" style="width: 230px;">
         <div style="margin:15px auto;">
          <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Matcha_and_wagashi_by_MShades_at_Daigoji,_Kyoto.jpg">
           <img alt="" data-file-height="2112" data-file-width="2816" height="150" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0a/Matcha_and_wagashi_by_MShades_at_Daigoji%2C_Kyoto.jpg/200px-Matcha_and_wagashi_by_MShades_at_Daigoji%2C_Kyoto.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0a/Matcha_and_wagashi_by_MShades_at_Daigoji%2C_Kyoto.jpg/300px-Matcha_and_wagashi_by_MShades_at_Daigoji%2C_Kyoto.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0a/Matcha_and_wagashi_by_MShades_at_Daigoji%2C_Kyoto.jpg/400px-Matcha_and_wagashi_by_MShades_at_Daigoji%2C_Kyoto.jpg 2x" width="200"/>
          </a>
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="gallerytext">
         <p>
          <a href="/wiki/Wagashi" title="Wagashi">
           Wagashi
          </a>
          (和菓子) served with
          <a href="/wiki/Matcha" title="Matcha">
           matcha
          </a>
          (抹茶)
         </p>
        </div>
       </div>
      </li>
     </ul>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Holidays">
       Holidays
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Main article:
      <a href="/wiki/Public_holidays_in_Japan" title="Public holidays in Japan">
       Public holidays in Japan
      </a>
     </div>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Young_ladies_at_Harajuku.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="412" data-file-width="674" height="134" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/22/Young_ladies_at_Harajuku.jpg/220px-Young_ladies_at_Harajuku.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/22/Young_ladies_at_Harajuku.jpg/330px-Young_ladies_at_Harajuku.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/22/Young_ladies_at_Harajuku.jpg/440px-Young_ladies_at_Harajuku.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Young_ladies_at_Harajuku.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        Young ladies celebrate
        <a href="/wiki/Coming_of_Age_Day" title="Coming of Age Day">
         Coming of Age Day
        </a>
        (成人の日
        <i>
         Seijin no Hi
        </i>
        ) in
        <a href="/wiki/Harajuku" title="Harajuku">
         Harajuku
        </a>
        ,
        <a href="/wiki/Tokyo" title="Tokyo">
         Tokyo
        </a>
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      Officially, Japan has 15 national, government-recognized holidays. Public holidays in Japan are regulated under the Public Holiday Law (国民の祝日に関する法律
      <i>
       Kokumin no Shukujitsu ni Kansuru Hōritsu
      </i>
      ) of 1948.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-302">
       <a href="#cite_note-302">
        [301]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Beginning in 2000, Japan implemented the
      <a href="/wiki/Happy_Monday_System" title="Happy Monday System">
       Happy Monday System
      </a>
      , which moved a number of national holidays to Monday in order to obtain a long weekend. In 2006, the country decided to add
      <a href="/wiki/Sh%C5%8Dwa_Day" title="Shōwa Day">
       Shōwa Day
      </a>
      , a new national holiday, in place of
      <a href="/wiki/Greenery_Day" title="Greenery Day">
       Greenery Day
      </a>
      on April 29, and to move Greenery Day to May 4. These changes took effect in 2007. In 2014, the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/House_of_Councillors" title="House of Councillors">
       House of Councillors
      </a>
      decided to add Mountain Day
      <span style="font-weight: normal">
       (
       <span class="t_nihongo_kanji" lang="ja">
        山の日
       </span>
       <span class="t_nihongo_comma" style="display:none">
        ,
       </span>
       <i>
        Yama no Hi
       </i>
       <sup class="t_nihongo_help noprint">
        <a href="/wiki/Help:Installing_Japanese_character_sets" title="Help:Installing Japanese character sets">
         <span class="t_nihongo_icon" style="color: #00e; font: bold 80% sans-serif; text-decoration: none; padding: 0 .1em;">
          ?
         </span>
        </a>
       </sup>
       )
      </span>
      to the Japanese calendar on August 11, after lobbying by the Japanese Alpine Club. It is intended to coincide with the
      <a href="/wiki/Bon_Festival" title="Bon Festival">
       Bon Festival
      </a>
      vacation time, giving Japanese people an opportunity to appreciate Japan's mountains.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-303">
       <a href="#cite_note-303">
        [302]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-304">
       <a href="#cite_note-304">
        [303]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      The national holidays in Japan are
      <a href="/wiki/Japanese_New_Year" title="Japanese New Year">
       New Year's Day
      </a>
      on January 1,
      <a href="/wiki/Coming_of_Age_Day" title="Coming of Age Day">
       Coming of Age Day
      </a>
      on Second Monday of January,
      <a href="/wiki/National_Foundation_Day" title="National Foundation Day">
       National Foundation Day
      </a>
      on February 11,
      <a href="/wiki/Vernal_Equinox_Day" title="Vernal Equinox Day">
       Vernal Equinox Day
      </a>
      on March 20 or 21,
      <a href="/wiki/Sh%C5%8Dwa_Day" title="Shōwa Day">
       Shōwa Day
      </a>
      on April 29,
      <a href="/wiki/Constitution_Memorial_Day" title="Constitution Memorial Day">
       Constitution Memorial Day
      </a>
      on May 3,
      <a href="/wiki/Greenery_Day" title="Greenery Day">
       Greenery Day
      </a>
      on May 4,
      <a href="/wiki/Children%27s_Day_(Japan)" title="Children's Day (Japan)">
       Children's Day
      </a>
      on May 5,
      <a href="/wiki/Marine_Day" title="Marine Day">
       Marine Day
      </a>
      on Third Monday of July,
      <a href="/wiki/Mountain_Day" title="Mountain Day">
       Mountain Day
      </a>
      on August 11,
      <a href="/wiki/Respect_for_the_Aged_Day" title="Respect for the Aged Day">
       Respect for the Aged Day
      </a>
      on Third Monday of September,
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Autumnal_Equinox" title="Autumnal Equinox">
       Autumnal Equinox
      </a>
      on September 23 or 24,
      <a href="/wiki/Health_and_Sports_Day" title="Health and Sports Day">
       Health and Sports Day
      </a>
      on Second Monday of October,
      <a href="/wiki/Culture_Day" title="Culture Day">
       Culture Day
      </a>
      on November 3,
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Labour_Thanksgiving_Day" title="Labour Thanksgiving Day">
       Labour Thanksgiving Day
      </a>
      on November 23, and
      <a href="/wiki/The_Emperor%27s_Birthday" title="The Emperor's Birthday">
       The Emperor's Birthday
      </a>
      on Desember 23.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-305">
       <a href="#cite_note-305">
        [304]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Festivals">
       Festivals
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Main article:
      <a href="/wiki/Japanese_festivals" title="Japanese festivals">
       Japanese festivals
      </a>
     </div>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:UenoParkHanami.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1198" data-file-width="1764" height="149" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e1/UenoParkHanami.jpg/220px-UenoParkHanami.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e1/UenoParkHanami.jpg/330px-UenoParkHanami.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e1/UenoParkHanami.jpg/440px-UenoParkHanami.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:UenoParkHanami.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        Popular Japanese festival,
        <a href="/wiki/Hanami" title="Hanami">
         Hanami
        </a>
        celebration at
        <a href="/wiki/Ueno_Park" title="Ueno Park">
         Ueno Park
        </a>
        ,
        <a href="/wiki/Tokyo" title="Tokyo">
         Tokyo
        </a>
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      There are many festivals in Japan, which are called in Japanese as
      <i>
       matsuri
      </i>
      (祭) which celebrate annually. There are no specific festival days for all of Japan; dates vary from area to area, and even within a specific area, but festival days do tend to cluster around traditional holidays such as
      <a href="/wiki/Setsubun" title="Setsubun">
       Setsubun
      </a>
      or
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Obon" title="Obon">
       Obon
      </a>
      . Festivals are often based around one
      <a class="mw-disambig" href="/wiki/Event" title="Event">
       event
      </a>
      , with food stalls,
      <a href="/wiki/Entertainment" title="Entertainment">
       entertainment
      </a>
      , and
      <a href="/wiki/Carnival" title="Carnival">
       carnival
      </a>
      <a href="/wiki/Game" title="Game">
       games
      </a>
      to keep people entertained. Its usually sponsored by a local
      <a href="/wiki/Shrine" title="Shrine">
       shrine
      </a>
      or
      <a href="/wiki/Temple" title="Temple">
       temple
      </a>
      , though they can be
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Secular" title="Secular">
       secular
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-jnto.go.jp_306-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-jnto.go.jp-306">
        [305]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Notable festival often feature processions which may include elaborate floats. Preparation for these processions is usually organised at the level of neighborhoods, or
      <i>
       machi
      </i>
      (町). Prior to these, the local
      <a href="/wiki/Kami" title="Kami">
       kami
      </a>
      may be ritually installed in
      <a href="/wiki/Mikoshi" title="Mikoshi">
       mikoshi
      </a>
      and paraded through the streets, such as
      <a href="/wiki/Gion" title="Gion">
       Gion
      </a>
      in
      <a href="/wiki/Kyoto" title="Kyoto">
       Kyoto
      </a>
      , and
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hadaka_matsuri" title="Hadaka matsuri">
       Hadaka
      </a>
      in
      <a href="/wiki/Okayama" title="Okayama">
       Okayama
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-jnto.go.jp_306-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-jnto.go.jp-306">
        [305]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Sports">
       Sports
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Main article:
      <a href="/wiki/Sport_in_Japan" title="Sport in Japan">
       Sport in Japan
      </a>
     </div>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Sumo_ceremony.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="375" data-file-width="500" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8c/Sumo_ceremony.jpg/220px-Sumo_ceremony.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8c/Sumo_ceremony.jpg/330px-Sumo_ceremony.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8c/Sumo_ceremony.jpg/440px-Sumo_ceremony.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Sumo_ceremony.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        <a href="/wiki/Sumo" title="Sumo">
         Sumo
        </a>
        wrestlers form around the referee during the ring-entering ceremony
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      Traditionally,
      <a href="/wiki/Sumo" title="Sumo">
       sumo
      </a>
      is considered Japan's national sport.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-307">
       <a href="#cite_note-307">
        [306]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <a href="/wiki/Japanese_martial_arts" title="Japanese martial arts">
       Japanese martial arts
      </a>
      such as
      <a href="/wiki/Judo" title="Judo">
       judo
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Karate" title="Karate">
       karate
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Kendo" title="Kendo">
       kendo
      </a>
      are also widely practiced and enjoyed by spectators in the country. After the Meiji Restoration, many Western sports were introduced in Japan and began to spread through the education system.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-308">
       <a href="#cite_note-308">
        [307]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Japan hosted the Summer Olympics in
      <a href="/wiki/1964_Summer_Olympics" title="1964 Summer Olympics">
       Tokyo in 1964
      </a>
      . Japan has hosted the Winter Olympics twice:
      <a href="/wiki/1972_Winter_Olympics" title="1972 Winter Olympics">
       Sapporo in 1972
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/1998_Winter_Olympics" title="1998 Winter Olympics">
       Nagano in 1998
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-309">
       <a href="#cite_note-309">
        [308]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Tokyo will host the
      <a href="/wiki/2020_Summer_Olympics" title="2020 Summer Olympics">
       2020 Summer Olympics
      </a>
      , making Tokyo the first Asian city to host the Olympics twice.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-310">
       <a href="#cite_note-310">
        [309]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Japan is the most successful Asian
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Rugby_Union" title="Rugby Union">
       Rugby Union
      </a>
      country, winning the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Asian_Five_Nations" title="Asian Five Nations">
       Asian Five Nations
      </a>
      a record 6 times and winning the newly formed
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/IRB_Pacific_Nations_Cup" title="IRB Pacific Nations Cup">
       IRB Pacific Nations Cup
      </a>
      in 2011. Japan will host the 2019 IRB
      <a href="/wiki/Rugby_World_Cup" title="Rugby World Cup">
       Rugby World Cup
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-311">
       <a href="#cite_note-311">
        [310]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      <a href="/wiki/Baseball_in_Japan" title="Baseball in Japan">
       Baseball
      </a>
      is currently the most popular spectator sport in the country. Japan's top professional league, now known as
      <a href="/wiki/Nippon_Professional_Baseball" title="Nippon Professional Baseball">
       Nippon Professional Baseball
      </a>
      , was established in 1936.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-312">
       <a href="#cite_note-312">
        [311]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Since the establishment of the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/J._League" title="J. League">
       Japan Professional Football League
      </a>
      in 1992, association football has also gained a wide following.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-313">
       <a href="#cite_note-313">
        [312]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Japan was a venue of the
      <a href="/wiki/Intercontinental_Cup_(football)" title="Intercontinental Cup (football)">
       Intercontinental Cup
      </a>
      from 1981 to 2004 and co-hosted the
      <a href="/wiki/2002_FIFA_World_Cup" title="2002 FIFA World Cup">
       2002 FIFA World Cup
      </a>
      with South Korea.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-314">
       <a href="#cite_note-314">
        [313]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Japan has one of the most successful football teams in Asia, winning the
      <a href="/wiki/AFC_Asian_Cup" title="AFC Asian Cup">
       Asian Cup
      </a>
      four times.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-315">
       <a href="#cite_note-315">
        [314]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Also, Japan recently won the
      <a href="/wiki/2011_FIFA_Women%27s_World_Cup" title="2011 FIFA Women's World Cup">
       FIFA Women's World Cup
      </a>
      in 2011.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-316">
       <a href="#cite_note-316">
        [315]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Golf is also popular in Japan,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-317">
       <a href="#cite_note-317">
        [316]
       </a>
      </sup>
      as are forms of auto racing like the
      <a href="/wiki/Super_GT" title="Super GT">
       Super GT
      </a>
      series and
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Formula_Nippon" title="Formula Nippon">
       Formula Nippon
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-318">
       <a href="#cite_note-318">
        [317]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The country has produced one
      <a href="/wiki/National_Basketball_Association" title="National Basketball Association">
       NBA
      </a>
      player,
      <a href="/wiki/Yuta_Tabuse" title="Yuta Tabuse">
       Yuta Tabuse
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-consulteny_319-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-consulteny-319">
        [318]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Media">
       Media
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Main article:
      <a href="/wiki/Media_of_Japan" title="Media of Japan">
       Media of Japan
      </a>
     </div>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:NHK_Osaka_Broadcasting_Station_Bldg_20060604-001.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2229" data-file-width="1482" height="331" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/51/NHK_Osaka_Broadcasting_Station_Bldg_20060604-001.jpg/220px-NHK_Osaka_Broadcasting_Station_Bldg_20060604-001.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/51/NHK_Osaka_Broadcasting_Station_Bldg_20060604-001.jpg/330px-NHK_Osaka_Broadcasting_Station_Bldg_20060604-001.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/51/NHK_Osaka_Broadcasting_Station_Bldg_20060604-001.jpg/440px-NHK_Osaka_Broadcasting_Station_Bldg_20060604-001.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:NHK_Osaka_Broadcasting_Station_Bldg_20060604-001.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        <a href="/wiki/NHK" title="NHK">
         NHK
        </a>
        Broadcasting Building in Osaka
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      <a href="/wiki/Television" title="Television">
       Television
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Newspaper" title="Newspaper">
       newspapers
      </a>
      take an important role in Japanese mass media, though
      <a href="/wiki/Radio" title="Radio">
       radio
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Magazine" title="Magazine">
       magazines
      </a>
      also take apart.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-nhk.or.jp_320-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-nhk.or.jp-320">
        [319]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-japanesestudies.org.uk_321-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-japanesestudies.org.uk-321">
        [320]
       </a>
      </sup>
      For a long time, newspapers were regarded as the most influential information medium in Japan, although audience attitudes towards television changed with the emergence of commercial news broadcasting in the mid-1980s.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-nhk.or.jp_320-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-nhk.or.jp-320">
        [319]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Over the last decade, television has clearly come to surpass newspapers as Japan's main information and entertainment medium.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-pressnet.or.jp_322-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-pressnet.or.jp-322">
        [321]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      There are 6 nationwide television networks, such as
      <a href="/wiki/NHK" title="NHK">
       NHK
      </a>
      ,
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Nippon_Television" title="Nippon Television">
       Nippon Television
      </a>
      (NTV),
      <a href="/wiki/Tokyo_Broadcasting_System" title="Tokyo Broadcasting System">
       Tokyo Broadcasting System
      </a>
      (TBS),
      <a href="/wiki/Fuji_Network_System" title="Fuji Network System">
       Fuji Network System
      </a>
      (FNS),
      <a href="/wiki/TV_Asahi" title="TV Asahi">
       TV Asahi
      </a>
      , and
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/TV_Tokyo_Network" title="TV Tokyo Network">
       TV Tokyo Network
      </a>
      (TXN).
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-japanesestudies.org.uk_321-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-japanesestudies.org.uk-321">
        [320]
       </a>
      </sup>
      For the most part, television networks were established based on capital investments by existing radio networks.
      <a href="/wiki/Japanese_variety_show" title="Japanese variety show">
       Variety shows
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Japanese_television_drama" title="Japanese television drama">
       serial dramas
      </a>
      , and
      <a href="/wiki/News" title="News">
       news
      </a>
      constitute a large percentage of Japanese television show. According to the fourth NHK survey on television viewing in Japan, 95 percent of Japanese watch television every day. The average daily duration of television viewing ranged from approximately four hours.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-323">
       <a href="#cite_note-323">
        [322]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Japanese readers have a choice of approximately 120 daily newspapers with a total of 50 million copies of 'set paper' with an average subscription rate of 1.13 newspapers per household.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-324">
       <a href="#cite_note-324">
        [323]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The main newspaper's publishers are
      <a href="/wiki/Yomiuri_Shimbun" title="Yomiuri Shimbun">
       Yomiuri Shimbun
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Asahi_Shimbun" title="Asahi Shimbun">
       Asahi Shimbun
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Mainichi_Shimbun" title="Mainichi Shimbun">
       Mainichi Shimbun
      </a>
      ,
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Nikkei_Shimbun" title="Nikkei Shimbun">
       Nikkei Shimbun
      </a>
      , and
      <a href="/wiki/Sankei_Shimbun" title="Sankei Shimbun">
       Sankei Shimbun
      </a>
      . According to a survey conducted by the Japanese Newspaper Association in June 1999, 85.4 per cent of men and 75 per cent of women read a newspaper every day. Average daily reading times vary with 27.7 minutes on weekdays and 31.7 minutes on holidays and Sunday.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-pressnet.or.jp_322-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-pressnet.or.jp-322">
        [321]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <div style="clear:both;">
     </div>
     <h2>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="See_also">
       See also
      </span>
     </h2>
     <div aria-label="Portals" class="noprint portal plainlist tright" role="navigation" style="margin:0.5em 0 0.5em 1em;border:solid #aaa 1px">
      <ul style="display:table;box-sizing:border-box;padding:0.1em;max-width:175px;background:#f9f9f9;font-size:85%;line-height:110%;font-style:italic;font-weight:bold">
       <li style="display:table-row">
        <span style="display:table-cell;padding:0.2em;vertical-align:middle;text-align:center">

        </span>
        <span style="display:table-cell;padding:0.2em 0.2em 0.2em 0.3em;vertical-align:middle">
         <a href="/wiki/Portal:Japan" title="Portal:Japan">
          Japan portal
         </a>
        </span>
       </li>
       <li style="display:table-row">
        <span style="display:table-cell;padding:0.2em;vertical-align:middle;text-align:center">
         <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Ic%C3%B4ne_Ile.svg">
          <img alt="icon" class="noviewer" data-file-height="200" data-file-width="200" height="28" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/87/Ic%C3%B4ne_Ile.svg/28px-Ic%C3%B4ne_Ile.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/87/Ic%C3%B4ne_Ile.svg/42px-Ic%C3%B4ne_Ile.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/87/Ic%C3%B4ne_Ile.svg/56px-Ic%C3%B4ne_Ile.svg.png 2x" width="28"/>
         </a>
        </span>
        <span style="display:table-cell;padding:0.2em 0.2em 0.2em 0.3em;vertical-align:middle">
         <a href="/wiki/Portal:Islands" title="Portal:Islands">
          Islands portal
         </a>
        </span>
       </li>
       <li style="display:table-row">
        <span style="display:table-cell;padding:0.2em;vertical-align:middle;text-align:center">
         <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Asia_(orthographic_projection).svg">
          <img alt="icon" class="noviewer" data-file-height="541" data-file-width="541" height="28" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/80/Asia_%28orthographic_projection%29.svg/28px-Asia_%28orthographic_projection%29.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/80/Asia_%28orthographic_projection%29.svg/42px-Asia_%28orthographic_projection%29.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/80/Asia_%28orthographic_projection%29.svg/56px-Asia_%28orthographic_projection%29.svg.png 2x" width="28"/>
         </a>
        </span>
        <span style="display:table-cell;padding:0.2em 0.2em 0.2em 0.3em;vertical-align:middle">
         <a href="/wiki/Portal:Asia" title="Portal:Asia">
          Asia portal
         </a>
        </span>
       </li>

          T. V. Paul; James J. Wirtz; Michel Fortmann (2005).
          <a class="external text" href="https://www.google.com/books?id=9jy28vBqscQC&amp;pg=PA59&amp;dq=" rel="nofollow">
           "Great+power"
           <i>
            Balance of Power
           </i>
          </a>
          . United States of America: State University of New York Press, 2005. pp. 59, 282.
          <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">
           ISBN
          </a>
          <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/0-7914-6401-6" title="Special:BookSources/0-7914-6401-6">
           0-7914-6401-6
          </a>
          .
         </cite>
         <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AJapan&amp;rft.au=James+J.+Wirtz&amp;rft.au=Michel+Fortmann&amp;rft.au=T.+V.+Paul&amp;rft.btitle=Balance+of+Power&amp;rft.date=2005&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3D9jy28vBqscQC%26pg%3DPA59%26dq%3D%22Great%2Bpower%22&amp;rft.isbn=0-7914-6401-6&amp;rft.pages=59%2C+282&amp;rft.place=United+States+of+America&amp;rft.pub=State+University+of+New+York+Press%2C+2005&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook">
          <span style="display:none;">
          </span>
         </span>
         <i>
          Accordingly, the great powers after the Cold War are Britain, China, France, Germany, Japan, Russia, and the United States
         </i>
         p.59

          <sup>
           <i>
            <b>
             a

          . OECD.

         <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AJapan&amp;rft.btitle=OECD.Stat+Education+and+Training+%3E+Education+at+a+Glance+%3E+Educational+attainment+and+labor-force+status+%3E+Educational+attainment+of+25-64+year-olds&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fstats.oecd.org%2F%23&amp;rft.pub=OECD&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook">

         , p. 145, at
         <a href="/wiki/Google_Books" title="Google Books">
          Google Books
         </a>
         ; excerpt: "emphasis on the undisrupted chronological continuity from myths to legends and from legends to history, it is difficult to determine where one ends and the next begins. At any rate, the first ten legendary emperors are clearly not reliable historical records."

         Boleslaw Szczesniak, "The Sumu-Sanu Myth. Notes and Remarks on the Jimmu Tenno Myth", in
         <a href="/wiki/Monumenta_Nipponica" title="Monumenta Nipponica">

        <span class="reference-text">

          <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1-85941-673-0" title="Special:BookSources/978-1-85941-673-0">

         <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AJapan&amp;rft.aufirst=Meryll&amp;rft.aulast=Dean&amp;rft.btitle=Japanese+legal+system%3A+text%2C+cases+%26+materials&amp;rft.date=2002&amp;rft.edition=2nd&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.isbn=978-1-85941-673-0&amp;rft.pages=131&amp;rft.pub=Cavendish&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook">
          <span style="display:none;">
          </span>

        </span>

       <li id="cite_note-90">
        <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
         <b>
          <a href="#cite_ref-90">
           ^
          </a>
         </b>
        </span>
        <span class="reference-text">
         In Japanese, 43 of the prefectures are called "ken" (県), Kyoto and Osaka are "fu" (府), Hokkaido is a "dō" (道) and Tokyo is a "to" (都). Although different in name they are functionally the same.
        </span>
       </li>

       <li id="cite_note-Dentsu2006-228">
        <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
         <b>
          <a href="#cite_ref-Dentsu2006_228-0">
           ^
          </a>
         </b>
        </span>
        <span class="reference-text">
         Dentsu Communication Institute, Japan Research Center:
         <i>
          <a class="external text" href="http://www2.ttcn.ne.jp/honkawa/9460.html" rel="nofollow">

          </a>

         (世界60カ国価値観データブック).
        </span>
       </li>

        <span class="reference-text">

          http://www.nhk.or.jp/bunken/book-en/b41011e.html#01-03
         </a>
        </span>
       </li>
       <li id="cite_note-324">
        <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
         <b>
          <a href="#cite_ref-324">
           ^
          </a>
         </b>
        </span>
        <span class="reference-text">
         <a class="external free" href="http://www.pressnet.or.jp/data/0101.htm" rel="nofollow">
          http://www.pressnet.or.jp/data/0101.htm
         </a>
        </span>
       </li>
      </ol>
     </div>
     <h2>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Notes">
       Notes
      </span>
     </h2>
     <div class="reflist" style="list-style-type: decimal;">
      <ol class="references">
       <li id="cite_note-229">
        <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
         <b>
          <a href="#cite_ref-229">
           ^
          </a>
         </b>
        </span>
        <span class="reference-text">
         Bestor, Yamagata. 2011. pp. 66-67: 無宗教
         <i>
          mushūkyō
         </i>
         , "no religion", in Japanese language and mindset identifies those people who do not belong to organised religion. To the Japanese, the term "religion" or "faith" means
         <a href="/wiki/Organized_religion" title="Organized religion">
          organized religions
         </a>
         on the model of Christianity, that is a religion with specific doctrines and requirement for church membership. So, when asked "what is their religion", most of the Japanese answer that they "do not belong to any religion". According to
         <a href="/wiki/NHK" title="NHK">
          NHK
         </a>
         studies, those Japanese who identify with
         <i>
          mushūkyō
         </i>
         and therefore do not belong to any organised religion, actually take part in the folk ritual dimension of
         <i>
          Shinto
         </i>
         . Ama Toshimaru in
         <i>
          Nihonjin wa naze mushukyo na no ka
         </i>
         ("Why are the Japanese non-religious?") of 1996, explains that people who do not belong to organised religions but regularly pray and make offerings to ancestors and protective deities at private altars or Shinto shrines will identify themselves as
         <i>
          mushukyo
         </i>
         . Ama designates "natural religion" what NHK studies define as "folk religion", and other scholars have named "Nipponism" (
         <i>
          Nipponkyō
         </i>
         ) or "common religion".
        </span>
       </li>
      </ol>
     </div>

       <a href="/wiki/DMOZ" title="DMOZ">
        DMOZ
       </a>
      </li>
      <li>
       <a class="external text" href="https://www.britannica.com/place/Japan" rel="nofollow">
        Japan
       </a>
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Encyclop%C3%A6dia_Britannica" title="Encyclopædia Britannica">
         Encyclopædia Britannica
        </a>
       </i>
       entry
      </li>
      <li>
       <a class="external text" href="http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-pacific-14918801" rel="nofollow">
        Japan
       </a>
       profile from
       <a href="/wiki/BBC_News" title="BBC News">
        BBC News
       </a>
      </li>
      <li>
       <a class="external text" href="http://www.oecd.org/japan/" rel="nofollow">
        Japan
       </a>
       from the
       <a href="/wiki/Organisation_for_Economic_Co-operation_and_Development" title="Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development">
        OECD
       </a>
      </li>
      <li>
       <img alt="" data-file-height="48" data-file-width="48" height="16" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f3/Gnome-globe.svg/16px-Gnome-globe.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f3/Gnome-globe.svg/24px-Gnome-globe.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f3/Gnome-globe.svg/32px-Gnome-globe.svg.png 2x" width="16"/>
       <a class="extiw" href="https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/Atlas_of_Japan" title="commons:Atlas of Japan">
        Wikimedia Atlas of Japan

                  <td class="navbox-list navbox-even hlist" colspan="2" style="width:100%;padding:0px">
                   <div style="padding:0em 0.25em">
                    <b>
                     Potential countries
                    </b>
                    <ul>
                     <li>
                      <i>
                       <span class="flagicon">

                  <th class="navbox-group" scope="row">
                   Foreign ministers
                  </th>
                  <td class="navbox-list navbox-odd hlist" style="text-align:left;border-left-width:2px;border-left-style:solid;width:100%;padding:0px">

                     <li>
                      <span class="flagicon">
                       <a href="/wiki/China" title="China">
                        <img alt="China" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="600" data-file-width="900" height="15" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fa/Flag_of_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China.svg/23px-Flag_of_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fa/Flag_of_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China.svg/35px-Flag_of_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fa/Flag_of_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China.svg/45px-Flag_of_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China.svg.png 2x" width="23"/>
                       </a>
                      </span>
                      <a href="/wiki/Wang_Yi_(politician)" title="Wang Yi (politician)">
                       Wang Yi
                      </a>
                     </li>
                     <li>
                      <span class="flagicon">
                       <a href="/wiki/Japan" title="Japan">
                        <img alt="Japan" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="600" data-file-width="900" height="15" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/9e/Flag_of_Japan.svg/23px-Flag_of_Japan.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/9e/Flag_of_Japan.svg/35px-Flag_of_Japan.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/9e/Flag_of_Japan.svg/45px-Flag_of_Japan.svg.png 2x" width="23"/>
                       </a>
                      </span>
                      <a href="/wiki/Fumio_Kishida" title="Fumio Kishida">
                       Fumio Kishida
                      </a>
                     </li>
                     <li>
                      <span class="flagicon">
                       <a href="/wiki/South_Korea" title="South Korea">
                        <img alt="South Korea" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="600" data-file-width="900" height="15" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/09/Flag_of_South_Korea.svg/23px-Flag_of_South_Korea.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/09/Flag_of_South_Korea.svg/35px-Flag_of_South_Korea.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/09/Flag_of_South_Korea.svg/45px-Flag_of_South_Korea.svg.png 2x" width="23"/>
                       </a>
                      </span>
                      <a href="/wiki/Yun_Byung-se" title="Yun Byung-se">
                       Yun Byung-se
                      </a>
                     </li>
                    </ul>
                   </div>
                  </td>
